We loaded up on assorted sushi, Japanese style fish-and-chips, deep-fried crab and chicken, yummy but gone-in-a split second fried asparagus, and assorted bento boxes. Oh, and of course vast quantities of sake! 

The highlight of the night was the "Pink Lady Roll" which was fun to look at but even tastier to eat! Now my Japanese clients and friends might say that this particular roll is an insane amount of food but American boys have big appetites!

The total for the night with tip came to about $32 per person. Not bad at all for tons of food and drink. The only room for improvement is that, like many of the other dining places in J-Town, the chairs and booths here are teeny-teeny-weeny. Four of us that night stand over six feet (6 1/2, 6'1, 6'2, 6'3 respectively) and, though not basketball tall, we were crammed in with elbows and knees knocking while dining. Ouch!
author: Richard T.

description:
I have come to realize that since I've moved to the city, my parents have taken more day trips down from Sacramento to "visit me".  So randomly on a week day, my parents picked me up from work & we drove over to Japantown.  Since we always eat @ the same places, we decided to change things up & pick a restaurant @ random.  Enter Kushi Tsuru.

The parents & I all settled fro dinner specials.  I got the Kushi bento which had kushiage (Japanese deep fried kebabs) of imitation crab, zucchini, & mushrooms; a small & slimy piece of baked eel; the agedashi tofu was hot but not very flavorful; & the cucumber salad was only lukewarm.  My mom got a Kaiseki bento which also had kushiage but hers had beef; the piece of salmon was really small but it was grilled nicely; but the sashimi was not fresh.  My dad got the Chirashi gozen bento which was the most elaborate one of all.  The sashimi fish was not fresh; the fried flounder was good & the grilled shrimp skewers with beef & veggies were nice also; & there was a read bean dessert which was unfortunately too sweet to the point of sour.

In summary, this was a decent place with fairly reasonable prices considering its prime location.  But keep in mind, you don't come here to eat for enjoyment; you come to eat for fuel.
author: Karen S.

description:
Hmmm. I was quite confused when i came here last night. 

Service was good, we got seated in about 5 mins and our waitress came right away, maybe a little too quickly. As my boyfriend and i finally figured out what to get, we got back her attention. He ordered the cold soba noodles and i ordered ramen, extra spicy. I decided to add a spicy shrimp roll with avocado, she looked reallllyyy, and i mean really confused. She kept asking if i wanted tempura shrimp and i said no, i explained it a few more times... and she finally said yes, nodded her head and said she has to ask the chef if he can make it.  She returned after a few minutes only to tell me that it as going to cost me 10$!!! That was pretty surprising. I saw on the menu, a spicy tuna roll was only 6$, meaning that a plain, non battered spicy shrimp roll should only cost about the same if anything less.

I ended up not getting it, but both our dishes came out great. I was super bummed because i was really in the mood for avocado. :( The bowl of ramen was pretty big and had a lot of noodles, it wasn't as spicy as i had hoped but it was delicious. The broth and the noodles were so perfectly made that i couldn't help but to drink the broth in addition to eating all my noodles. I've never had soba noodle as my own dish before, but after taste testing the boyfriends, i might just reconsider it. It's weird eating noodles cold but the broth has a lot of flavors. 

If you decide to eat here, only get whats on the menu.  Food is tasty, good quality and at a relatively good price (for whats on the menu).
author: Lisa H.

description: My friends and I went there for lunch. Remember to ask for the lunch menu. I had the Beef Teriyaki which are very tasty and tender. Some of us had bento boxes and they looked good as well.
author: Tuan Anh P.

description: Nice meal. The lunch special bento box is a bit small, but the beef teriyaki was excellent. Their beef don and chicken don were tasty. Will come again.
author: Gilbert W.

description: First of all, they don't have any kushikatsu, so the name is a misnomer. Typical j town Japanese fare, nothing unusual, nothing surprising on the menu. The service is slow but given dinner rush, okay for a Saturday night. Food was alright, my Katsura curry was crisp tonkatsu over rice and curry was good but nothing spectacular. Overall okay but don't go out of your way to come here
author: Stan K.

description:
Just had lunch here and would definitely NOT recommend. Food was below par for Jtown and for Japanese food period. I ordered a spicy tuna roll- at first glance the color of the tuns just looked wrong and curiously it came with cucumber that was not seeded at all; you could literally see the seeds. On top of that, the rice was mushy and almost mealy. I took one bite and couldn't bring myself to eat the other 5 pieces. The shrimp and vegetable tempura were completely greasy and inedible. Thee was so much breeding that I hard time finding the shrimp/very thinly sliced vegetable. It was basically all batter and a mouthful of grease to boot.

We thought that this restaurant would be decent because there were so many people inside. Then after getting our very unappetizing food, we realized it was because its the first restaurant going into "restaurant alley."  Do NOT make the mistake of coming here unless you enjoy subpar food.
author: Christina C.

description: Its okay but nothing to write home about. Decent quality but I'd rather go to miyabitei in mitsuwa market (sj) and get a cheaper meal with the same quality. Come here only if you can't figure out where else to go in japantown, but skip if you're trying to get the best of the best.
author: Samantha D.

description:
This is my fav sushi spot in Japantown because it's good and casual. I don't really believe in fancy sushi restaurants. I'm already paying for high quality fish I can eat raw; I don't want to have to pay for the atmosphere too. 

There's an older Asian lady that's always trying to tell us what to order. It's kind of funny, though scary at first. Otherwise, the rest of the staff are nice.

I always try something new when I go in and I haven't yet been disappointed. My latest order was curry udon beef, which rocked my world. And it was perfect on a cold, SF day.
author: Apple C.

description:
Stopped in here for lunch with a few friends visiting the city as we explored Japantown mall. All I can say is I was extremely underwhelmed. It was a meal and something in our stomachs to digest.

Nothing about it was terrible, but the best thing about the meal was the miso soup at the beginning. The sushi seemed below average quality/freshness.

Overall, everything was just okay and I wish we had gone somewhere else. I'd recommend trying a different restaurant.
author: Tim K.

description:
I had a meeting here by and stopped by JapanTown for lunch. 

Sashimi is not fresh and the combination portions are tiny. Totally not worth it.
author: Tommy W.

description:
I rather liked it!

Of all the restaurants in and around the Geary street Japan Town mall area --practically stacked on top of each other-- I chose this one based on the menu alone.  My girlfriend and I were in town for a concert and wanted a good Bento meal.  Walking around the Japan Town district and the mall, we decided on this place and were completely happy that we did.

I ordered the Soba Bento ($12) which I found to be a downright bargain, considering the light and fluffy tempura (half veggies, half prawns) and the delicious sashimi (albacore, hamachi and proper tuna).  My girlfriend ordered the Chirashi Gozen Bento ($15), which was a LOT of food!  See: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/gn5poUrTw5grzKhwNy_3pg?select=Fdi_Iw1xyxlqEOjfcgE2mg We ended up splitting each other's meals and I have to say, the deep fried flounder was very tasty!  

Being a Reno resident without a car, I don't get to SF as much as I'd like to, but I will definitely go back to Kushi Tsuru again, given the chance.
author: Austin A.

description:
Im a little surprised by the wide array of reviews on this place. I went with a group of seven people on a Saturday for lunch. We kinda had low expectations because well its Japantown and we wanted actual Japanese food... but we were all really pleasantly surprised, including the Japanese guy with us and my hubby who lived in Japan.

I had agedashi tofu and sake kama, both excellent. everyone else had either bento, ramen, or some sort of katsu. Everyone was pleased, service was adequate and not note-worthy (a good thing, sometimes). Price was fine, not cheeeeeeeap but not bad at all, certainly nothing to whine about ;)  Even though the restaurant was busy and the Japan center was full of people, we managed to get seated asap. 

I would go back, if the entire group happens to have a yen for japanese food in nihonmachi.
author: Dama J.

description: Really enjoyed the Japanese comfort food here at Kushi Tsuru.  Had Katsu Curry, Yakitori, and some seafood salad.  It was all excellent except it was weird to have beef in the curry with the pork Katsu on top.  I'm sure there are better places in Japantown, but it was relatively quiet, the service was good, and the prices were reasonable.  Only funny part was that the people in the booth next to us had a really cute little baby and so we got to listen to their Wheels on the Bus playlist for most of our meal.
author: Chris A.

description: Rolls keep falling apart no matter how you pick them up, and the portions of the rolls are too small, and you pay top dollar for basically half a meal. I wouldn't recommend this place to anyone.
author: Anton R.

description: This place wasn't bad.  The food was good, I  had the combination plate with Teriyaki Chicken, Vegetable Tempura and California Roll. The serving was more than I expected which was definitely a plus and the food itself was reasonably priced. However, I had to give it three stars because of the not-so-attentive service and the establishment's lack of AC.
author: Julius Kenneth V.

description:
Tonkotsu Miso Ramen ($8.95) was good, but it was not memorable. I wouldn't suggest ordering this at all. The problem was not the ramen or the broth, it was the meat that came with it. The meat is about the size of a credit card and as thick as two credit card stacked on top of eat other. You only get ONE slice. Basically, you're paying for labor considering a Top Ramen will cost you about 25 cent on a bad day. 

The mango roll was pretty yummy. 
The Dragon Roll was different from previous places. They put carrots inside and the eel was tiny, tiny. Is the carrot normal? I don't know. It was my first time.

The best thing is that they validate for parking.
author: Jess W.

description:
I hate to complain, especially since my friend was gracious enough to pick up the tab, but I was thoroughly dissatisfied with the place, specifically the tonkotsu ramen ($9.50, I think). 

Sure, it had the noodles, the milky broth, the single slice of swirled naruto fish cake, the beni shoga, the occasional bean sprouts, and a piece of pork, but did it have to be cut at the thinnest setting you can possibly get with a deli slicer? It was about two and half inches in diameter (at its widest), about a millimeter and a half thick and all of it fat, even. 

And that sad little slice of Babe was supposed to justify spending $1 more than regular ramen?

Some have compared the ramen itself to packaged, instant noodles. I'd argue that it's just slightly better than that, although you're certainly not getting freshly made ones. The broth was about as salty as instant noodles, though.  

Service was barely existent. I don't like to be bothered throughout a meal, but if someone asks for water or the check, please bring it. One of our party asked for water when the tea was brought and didn't get it 'til he was finished with his curry. 

Since we were on a time constraint (which wouldn't have been an issue had things arrived when we estimated - food took forever to come out and service was slow), my friend flagged down the server/owner(?) for the check. After more than 20 minutes of waiting, he got up to go request it at the counter only to be stopped by said server/owner(?) halfway there with a shrewd, "You need something?!" that the whole restaurant could hear. 

Ugh.. 

I've got a soft spot for Japanese restaurants that still have the plastic food in the window, but this is not one of them.
author: Christine A.

description:
BEST UDON EVER.

I've tried Udon at other Japanese restaurants and this has got to be my favorite place. The noodles are thick and chewy! Plus the broth is tasty and light! Mmmm! I usually get the Niku Udon which has beef, green onions and fish cake. I would highly recommend this if you want something simple!!!

If you were wondering how the other food is, I would say it's good for its price. They have a wide variety of foods such as sushi, curry, ramen, and more! But if you are craving some delicious udon, this place is the spot! You will not be disappointed!
author: Junie Y.

description:
If anything you should get the bento boxes.  Otherwise the rolls and sashimi are overpriced.  In terms of the quality of fish they used, it was very fresh.  Also the consistency was good.  Quantity wise, it was meager. For a minute I thought our server was mute (no, not a typo... as in can't speak).

Ordered the 5 pc sake and pink lady roll.  DW got the veggie bento.

Food - 4
Service - 2
Price - 3*
Cleanliness - 4
Ambiance - 3

*I would say "Meh. I've experienced better" but in all honesty this is a fair rating since quality was good.
author: Eugene P.

description:
I've come here twice, both times i was very satisfied with the quality of their sushi. I've only had their sushi, so this review is based on that. The freshness and cut of their sashimi is melt in your mouth. 

Their rolls are very flavorful and attractively architectured. The only downside is, I wish they had a larger selection of rolls... But their menu is pretty big with alot of other japanese food, so I guess it balances out and I cant complain.. but i loveeee my sushi. Much rather have sushi than udon anyday.

Rainbow roll is win :)
sashimi platter is winwin :)

Other yelpers here have complained about the service being slow.. maybe that just happens @lunch.. I've only been here for dinner (and kinda @a late hour) and the service has been great. Not slow, and on point about the tea and asking if we're doing ok. but hey, if the sushi is good, i wouldn't mind the service being slow. Better to take your time preparing good food than rushing and effing it up.

oh and FYI, This is a japanese restaurant run by koreans, though i'm not sure if the chefs are korean. 

love how its open late too!
author: Angela C.

description:
This is very much the same as most Japantown establishments.
It's ok - but not the best you could find.

The chicken katsu curry tasted like it came from a box, or something that could be made by ourselves which isn't a bad thing but then at home it don't cost this much!

I mean it filled the spot, was hot and the katsu cripsy.
Beyond that, it didn't move me.
author: Nick L.

description:
Finally, sushi on the West Coast! This Midwestern girl = very happy.

My bf and I met up with several friends who were gathering in Japantown the eve of the 2nd annual Renegade Craft Fair. We found a place in the plaza across from our hotel. 

It was nice to see friends again in this simple restaurant. The food wasn't mind-blowing, but it was just nice to have fairly decent Asian food. 

I ordered the soba bento which came with soba, tempura, and a few pieces of nigiri and vegetable roll. Everything was pretty average. One thing that stood out was the chirashi--the fish was pretty fresh & delicious. 

One complaint: they didn't put any wasabi in my nigiri pieces which was disappointing!

3 stars!
author: Joyce H.

description: THIS PLACE NEEDS TO WASH THEIR BOWLS/PLATES BETTER! Two times I've found either leftover rice or onion laying on them. But the food, it was alright. Miso soup was average. Udon was good but needed more fishcake! The white tuna roll was alright. Nothing special. And I've had better caterpillar roll. They used imitation crab meat  Overall, this place was decent for its lunch special price.
author: Joanne K.

description:
It was okay. The food was well prepared, and the server was almost friendly.
The portions were on the smaller side and I didn't find the food to be well seasoned nor tasty....
author: Filipe G.

description:
I used to go there often a few years ago; I never really liked it but my ex did for some reason, so I didn't really have a choice. I just went back for the first time in ~4 years. and things are pretty much the same... maybe a bit worse. Fish is not fresh; our salmon sahimi was still very cold (read: still a bit frozen) inside and smelled very fishy. The rest of the food varied from mediocre to meh. Service is not really good either. 
Avoid this place if you can. I only give one star when I have a truly horrifying experience so they get 2 because it is "just" bad.
author: Vithiet L.

description: Literally just there 30 minutes ago. We ordered Tempura don and tonkatsu. Tempura came out in less than 5min and my tonkatsu took more than 15minutes....tempura and tonkatsu are both fried, you can just throw it in together in the fryer. Didn't want to wait for Tonkatsu anymore so we just left. The tempura don even got cold. This restaurant was my main spot since high school. I think they changed management and cooks. I will no longer return here and recommend this place ever again. Sorry, but I think this place will close down soon. Maybe I'll come back to try when it's a different place.
author: Emme C.

description:
This is actually one of my preferred Japanese places to eat at when in Japantown. The prices are fair, the ambiance is simple and clean, and the service is nice. They accept credit cards and will split your check. Side note: green tea is free.

I always order a Soba Bento for $12. Comes with cold soba noodles, 3 veggie sushi, 3 sashimi, miso soup, and some tempura. Gets me full, tastes pretty good.

They'll see me coming back often.
author: Paul B.

description:
Sorry, but we were not very impressed at all with Kusi Tsuru. There is much better sushi in about four different restaurants with the one block area.

The place was not very busy and the food, including the sushi was definitely below average.
author: Finnegan M.

description:
Food here is getting worse. Not going there again. Worse is the service. Food came out really late and they forgot two of our dishes. They also did not take it out from our bill and still charged for food we never got. When I told them that they forgot this menu, they said they were actually out of hotate. So they didn't tell me that they were out of it, and knew they never served it, but had no problem putting it on a bill?

This business should go down. Don't go here. Restaurant next door has same menu.
author: Esther L.

description:
Good food, terrible service.
We were enjoying Japan Town, and wanted to get some lunch. This place wasn't busy, but the food other people were enjoying looked good, and the price was right so we decided to give it a try.
Luckily I decided to glance at other Yelp reviews really quick, and saw "terrible service" and "avoid the sushi", even so we figured if we expected it, no biggie, plus we weren't in any hurry, and wanted to enjoy a nice long lunch.
True to form almost immediately, it must have been 15 minutes or so before someone came to take our order. There was maybe one other couple in the restaurant. She didn't write it down, and attempted to repeat it back to us 3 times, wrong, before she seemed to get it.
We went with the bento box lunch special, which is $9.95 for two items, miso soup, salad, rice, and 2 pieces of California roll.
A long time seemed to pass before we finally got our food. Luckily it was actually quite delicious! The salad dressing they use was just really good. My tempura shrimp were large and fluffy and tasted great. Even the California roll was really good. The katsu was a little on the bland side but the dipping sauce they give you fixed that right up.
During the time we were eating, I really wanted a glass of water, at this time there was another couple, and a group of 4 in addition to us in the restaurant. I could not get the one waitress' attention at all when she would come to check on the others, but never checked on us. There were 3 other waitresses all sitting around together at a back table, on their phones, talking and not doing anything. I gave up on my glass of water, we finished our lunch, paid and left.
So our food was very good, but just very poor service. Lunch box deal is really good, so I would say worth a shot as long as you know what to expect.
author: Omi P.

description:
Ok for a free dinner it was awesome. The sashimi platter was pretty fresh, although no the most fresh I've had, but it was still good. 

There was this roll that was soooo good I forgot what it was called, but there's a picture I posted of it. Yummy. 

I also got this combo plate with teriyaki, salad, sashimi and something else but it was pretty filling for about $10. 

It's not disappointing since it is located in Japantown so it's trustworthy for a decent sushi meal :)
author: Quinallison D.

description:
Came here  with my father a few nights ago for dinner. I've been coming to Kushi Tsuru for years and noticed last fall that the space was being renovated. Turns out they have new owners. 

Pros: They let me get two salads, one in place of the rice/bento box. The service was actually quite good. And they allowed my father to get a bento box with the BBQ ribs. The menu on the window was apparently a lunch menu. Portions were of good size. 

Cons: Was this a non-Japanese chef following recipes? 

I ordered the bento box - 3 items for $16: Saba, a CA Roll, and Vegetable Tempura. The CA Roll rice didn't have the vinegar mix in with the rice; the rice was quite plain. The roll also fell apart. The Saba was overcooked/dry and flavorless. The Tempura was bland. Looked right, but didn't taste much like anything. 

My father was able to order the two items he saw on the menu in the window: BBQ Ribs and Tonkatsu bento. The Tonkatsu was overcooked as was the ribs. he said both were bland, even with the sauce that they provided. 

I'm going to take a guess and say that the new owners, or at least the chef, is not Japanese. Food looks about right but it's not J-town. 

Too bad as I have good memories of eating here with my family for many years. Did the former owner retire?
author: Akiki A.

description:
I like this place.  I've been here 3 times in 3 weeks.  I always get the Chicken Karaage Curry and the Green Dream roll which is a veggie roll with seaweed and tofu and avocado.  yummy.  service is decent too.

However, the two things that knock it down a couple of stars for me are the prices.  I just feel like it's a bit pricey for the quality.  that's no knock on the quality of the food but i have had similar food for much less.  maybe it's because it's in jtown in the middle of restaurant row.  but yeah if the prices lowered, i'd bump up my rating.
author: Ray R.

description: Good vegetarian curry rice, plus lots of veggie sushi rolls on their "green menu."
author: k n.

description:
The bf and I went to japantown today and was intending to go somewhere else but they happen to be closed. We also almost went next door to mifune because there was a 15 minute wait for Kushi Tsuru and we were starving. However, we came back when we found out MiFune was more of a noodle shop. I got the kushi bento and oyatama roll(?) and the bf got the 9 piece sashimi and mango roll. The rolls were FANTASTIC. They were a good portion and were very tasty. My bf really enjoyed the mango roll's puree sauce. The kushi bento was good too though I wish there was an extra piece of eel since I love eel. We spent $60 with tip but it was pretty good portion of food. 

We didn't have any issues with the service either but right when we sat down and they took our order, they got busy again so the waiter was a bit flustered with the other customers. The only thing was that we did order a uni nigari and they sent out a unagi nigari but our waiter was quick to turn it back and realized the mistake when we stated that we wanted uni. They didn't have uni though that day.
author: Tao Tao W.

description:
My friends and I had trouble deciding on a spot to eat in Japantown so we settled for Kushi Tsuru because of the ramen lunch specials and also because the prices were reasonable... unlike that Korean BBQ spot, Seoul Garden. O_o

I had the chicken katsu, which I really liked since it was pretty light. Not hella heavy like L&L's Hawaiian BBQ. The miso soup was awesome! This spot was pretty quaint and low-key, not too busy for a Friday afternoon in the city. 

The service was spotty; it was a little difficult to get a hold of our server at times but it wasn't so bad to the point to the point of b-tching and complaining. And they validate parking so that's a plus.
author: April P.

description:
This is intended to be a review of the bathroom
It convinced us to not eat here

Also, if you are looking for a selection kushi katsu or similar due to the naming of the restaurant,  I observed only one or two such items in the menu

Seems geared toward americanized sushi
author: Satoru Y.

description:
Wow... This place was just AMAZING!!! I ordered the combo of chicken teriyaki and the tempura.The prices was a little bit over priced,but I didn't mind.Also,I got the coupon for checking in on Yelp. Overall, a very good place to eat lunch.I don't know why other people give it low ratings,but I liked it.

P.S Please excuse me if my english is bad because this is my first review.
author: Vincent W.

description: Horrible service. The food was alright. Our "spider roll " didn't look like no damn roll like it was one the menu. Waitress never checked up on us. Even though we were the only customers thrre. -_- ' not going there again.
author: Eran C.

description: I was super hungry walking around and saw that this place was crowded and decided to give it a try. What a mistake that was. I ordered a Chicken Katsu Curry, because I thought it would be impossible to mess up. I was wrong. When the dish came out, the chicken was luke warm almost cold and the curry was bland. I put a bunch of the crush pepper on their and that couldn't even help it. As mentioned I was super hungry and didn't even put a dent in my food.
author: Tiffany N.

description:
Very expensive. Food was good, not great. Staff was friendly.

Did I say Freaken Expensive? Dinner price for lunch.
author: Mario A.

description:
I came in this place and I wasn't expecting anything spectacular. The place is fairly small which makes the service quick and responsive to the customers. Their menu is quite extensive. Everything from sushi and sashimi, bento boxes, and noodles. It took me at least 15 minutes before I finally decided on something, because everything sounded so tasty. Sometimes I think I would have an easier time deciding over a menu if I had more than one stomach. 

I decided on the Chirashi which was top of the line. It came with a cup of Miso which tasted just right. It's been my experience in other Japanese restaurants that Miso can be a bit overly salty (normally chains like Benihana's or Shogun) 

Great little place in Japantown with tasty looking menu and excellent service.
author: Nicholas M.

description:
Came here for dinner to celebrate the GF's birthday last week while we were visiting SF. It was kind of impromptu that we decided to eat here since we were wandering around Japantown and decided it would be more convenient than searching for other options.

We had the Sukiyaki, 49er roll and the Kushi Bento Box to share. We were going to get the Shabu Shabu but the waitress suggested the Sukiyaki instead because it has more flavor and we were happy to accept the suggestion.

The 49er roll came out first and while it had the standard serving of ginger that accompanies sushi, it was strangely missing the wasabi. We had to request for the wasabi and it was like the waitress was surprised that we wanted it. This happened to another table next to us too, so we weren't sure if they just wanted to emphasize the taste of their sushi or whatever. The roll was OK and they mixed things up by adding a bit of lemon to the roll.

The Sukiyaki was good and the beef was full of flavor in a broth that also had some veggies. The Kushi Bento was a good deal at $10 but everything was pretty average. Overall the food was OK but as a visitor in SF I'd look elsewhere for Japanese food. Bonus star for the waitress' honesty though.
author: Tim Y.

description:
Looking for lunch in Japantown I decided to try Kushi Tsuru. They offer sushi, combination and Bento traditional meals.

I ordered the Soba special ($11.00) which consisted of cold buckwheat noodles, tempura, keppa maki, 3 pcs of Nigiri and miso soup. I was in the mood for the Soba noodles and they were pleasant tasting. The tempura was not greasy, fried nice and crispy. The nigiri was not of super quality but I figured this was an add on to everything else. The lunch specials ranged from $9.50 to $18.00.

Good service and very nice atmosphere in Japantown.
author: Jim D.

description:
i remember eating here once when i was in high school...and that should've been the last.  BUT...tonight, i thought to myself, hey, why not give this place a try again?

japanese food in japantown has always been pretty mediocre...japantown is just not so japanese anymore.  anyhoo, we were hungry...and the plastic food looked good.  haha.

the service was great...the server lady was super nice and was awesome with catering to my no sesame seeds on anything request.  i ordered the california bento box...that included chicken teriyaki, fried fish, tuna sashimi, california roll, miso soup. and salad...all for under 10 bucks.  the server quickly came back to me saying that the california rolls are already pre-made and that i could substitute it for anything else in my bento box...already made???  hmm...there goes the freshness button being thrown out the window.  anyhoo, i asked for extra tuna sashimi.  my order literally came with 3-4 pieces of bite size chicken...5 pieces of tuna sashimi....a little piece of fried fish..and a heaping amount of salad.  

wifey's meal was a little better...she had the chirashi bento box...two bowls of chirashi, one was vegetarian while the other had 3 slices of sashimi.  it also came with cooked fish, a couple of skewers, and a red bean dessert.  this meal was around 15 dollars.  the fish was semi-fresh...no wow status.  the skewers were tasty...each one came with beef, zucchini, onions, and shrimp.  the cooked fish was also pretty decent...but nothing to jump up and down about.  

all in all, it was an ok dinner...it'll probably be another 10+ years again before i give this place another try.
author: Jen W.

description: Had a beautiful lunch here today. I uploaded a pic. Fiery island was awesome.
author: John D.

description:
Came here with my sister in early April 2010.

I'm still learning my way around sushi and I think Kushi Tsuru was really great.
The staff was really patient with us and accommodated my kiwi fruit allergy amazingly well. 

I'll be sure to visit when I visit Nor Cal again.
author: Alfa S.

description: I love ikayaki (grilled squid) and this place does the dish justice. It's a great restaurant to enjoy a solid dish with salad, rice and miso while people watching patrons in Japan Center.
author: Ilem E.

description:
I don't know why this place only has 3 stars!! How sad.  

My friend is a HUGE fan of Tempura and she always makes us eat here when we are in Japantown because they have the best Tempura there.  I'm not complaining.  I always get the sukiyaki, which I highly recommend!! It's perfect, aside from it not having my favorite ingredient: takenoko (bamboo shoots).  

Give this place a chance!
author: Jessyca M.

description:
Say, after you had a meal at a restaurant, 
you said, " taste like my home." or " The taste same as my mom made." would be a compliment, isn't it?

But, every time when I hear it, I am thinking 2 things.
1: I must say that your mom is good cook.
2: Or, " Gee! The cook must be an amateur like your mom."

Btw, 
when you are in a curry place in Japan and said, " The curry tastes same as my mom made." 
that would be a big insult.

I noticed that there are new large poster in the Kintetsu Mall lately and one got my attention was Katsu Curry over rice at Kushi Tsuru.
And, I saw a guy who were having it threw the window.
Shame on me, even though I hate to be inside because people are watching you eating but I could not help myself.
I am a Katsu Curry Whore.

I think I have a few things whore for.
I am a dumpling whore.
I am a pork bun whore.
I am a fried curry bun whore.
I am a Pho whore.
I am a sesame dumpling wore.
I am a chicken Katsu sandwich whore.
I am a bibimbup whore.
I am a Korean Spicy Chirashi whore.
I am a Okinimiyaki whore.
I am a piroshki whore. ( fried kind.)
I am a red velvet cake whore.
etc.

So, I got the Chicken Katsu Curry,9 bucks.
The Chicken Katsu was like Chicken Nuggets from Mac.
I am not kidding.
and the curry was exactly like my mom makes.
House Vermont Curry!
She always use the instant curry cube.
My mom wasn't good cook.
At all.
So, I am sayin' the curry at the Kushi-Tsuru is RIP-OFF!

Sorry mon, but I can't lie, but I still love you.
author: Nobu K.

description:
The food here is NOT bad by any means. It's just also not sh**mypants amazing. But it's satisfying.

What I love about this restaurant--love love love love love--is their "green menu." Every restaurant should have a green menu. I think it's supposed to be a "healthier" menu, but for me it's a "heavenlier" menu. Now, the meals that are served as soup (udon, soba) have the option of being made with kombu / seaweed broth. They always tell me there is no fish in that broth whatsoever (bonito, etc), so I'm really taking their word for it, but if it's the case, most of the items on their Green Menu ought to be vegan / vegetarian (with the possible exclusion of some sauces that come on the sushi or other items--always check!--and miso soup, which is almost never vegetarian because of the use of bonito/fish). So props to kushi tsuru for being one of the very few Japanese places where people with diets like mine are able to eat happily and heartily ^.^.. 

The service is always supremely friendly. I don't live in sf, but this is my Japanese restaurant of choice whenever I'm in the vicinity of Japantown. I've come here twice, months apart, and the Green Menu was there both times. As such, I'll return, and I hope that said menu remains.. forevermore. !!!!
author: Kyle G.

description: Having a craving for sushi, I knew I had to get my fix. I was confused about this place at first because it appeared to be attached to mifune?? Anywhoo, I was sucked into their display of special rolls so I came in. I got a salmon and mango passion. The mango passion was tarty with fruit. Service was a bit slow for two rolls. It was about 15 - 20 mins wait? The mango passion was topped with fresh mango and drizzled with kiwi sauce. I highly recommend this to all you fruit lovers out there. The salmon roll was relatively fresh as well.
author: Virginia Y.

description: I've been coming here for years now. If I want a quick quiet  meal with some ramen, I'd go there if I am in the area. But, the last time I went there, my ramen was extremely salty. It was as salty as a salt pretzel at the Pier. Don't get me wrong, this place is still great, but I guess the ramen is what you have to watch out for. The sushi there is pretty good, I still go there for sushi every now and then. Nice people as well.
author: Cynthia D.

description: Sashimi is very good here and not too expensive either. The service is great, the seating, very clean place and service can be a bit faster but overall I would definitely come back. The sushi rolls are very good and just like any japanese food, it's a work of art. I could not stop taking pictures of all our order before devouring them. I just love how Japanese food come to you looking so beautiful and still makes my tummy happy :)
author: Ateh M.

description:
I think this is one of the better Japanese restaurants inside Nihonmachi. Like, it is seriously affordable and the service is pretty good. 
It's nicely lit and has a very sleek, modern look to the restaurant. 
I actually really like the Nabeyaki Udon. It's a good balance between seafood, veggies and chicken and the broth is super yummy.
My sister and mom got their California Bento boxes while my dad got the Shabu Shabu. They were all very satisfied with the portion size and tastes of everything.
Not one of the busiest restaurants inside the mall but it's definitely not dead, especially on a Saturday night, a little after 8pm.
author: Susan Y.

description:
California Bento

Before I walked in, I thought this place was lively since I saw a lot of people sitting down. I walked in, and was quite fooled. This was small. Maybe 30 people at most? I thought the place next door was also apart of this. There was no line so we were seated immediately. The server was attentive but apparently did not get my friend's order right the first time. They made the change very quick and that was pleasant. 

I ordered the California Bento. It came with Grilled chicken teriyaki, tuna sashimi, deep fried fish,California roll 2pcs, salad, served with miso soup and rice. 
Everything came out very nicely organized and definitely great on the eyes. The food was average. Not the best but not the worst. I ate most of it except the Tuna Sashimi. I'm not a big fan of raw fish so I only had one piece just to try it. Not for me.
author: Lorth K.

description:
Very disappointed with the food here. I should've checked with Yelp first. Or at least I should've known not to patronize a gimmicky restaurant that gouges prices targeting tourists. For $13.56 ($12.50 pre-tax), I ordered a combination lunch "special." Trust me, there was nothing special or memorable about this meal except for the price I paid for it. I ordered the chicken teriyaki and katsu. This meal comes with a scoop of rice and miso soup, nothing else. The packaging was good, nice, and secure. The service is pretty friendly here. 

However, when we got to our destination, I was shocked to see how little we received in terms of portion size. I'm a pretty big guy, and I knew right then and there that I'd still be hungry. Both chicken dishes were like strips. It tasted like dark meat, instead of white chicken breast. On top of that, the katsu sauce was more like soy sauce. Now I know why it was so empty. I should've risked waiting longer at a more established and reputable restaurant instead of anticipating a short wait time for crap food. Yuck, never again.
author: Andy P.

description:
I felt as if the place could be a lot better.. They have the potential, but lack delivery.

I ordered the Tonkotsu ramen and the broth wasn't quite as good as I was hoping. It was lacking flavor and they give you a small sliver of pork. The noodles that they use remind me of the kind in Maruchan top ramen. Definitely not what I was expecting, especially since they are located right in the center of Japan town... 

I do have to admit that they have really good tea. haha
author: Keith O.

description:
I used to always come here with my brother and mom and I remember it to be good; however, my brother and I came today and I was extremely disappointed.

1) the waitress messed up our order and when another brought the food, she looked annoyed at us 
2) the tekka rolls we ordered were small and badly cut (just shows how much they care)
3) the food was okay, but not that great. 

Next time we will try a different restaurant.
author: Jane Z.

description:
I came when I was back in middle school, and this place worked for me back then, but now I find it mediocre. The portions are pretty small, and my friend and i admitted that we weren't really full by the end of our meal. We had to go get a crepe afterwards to fill our stomachs.

I usually got the unagi-don and they're always stingy with the unagi. There's always leftover rice that goes uneaten because there's not enought unagi. (And yes, I do try to split up my unagi proportionate to my rice) And my friend also found their udon average quality. 

During my last visit, I smelt this odor around us and even on the table. I recognized the odor on the table and it's from the towel they used to wipe it clean, shows that their cloth isn't that sanitary :\

I don't think I'll be paying this place any visits anymore.
author: Harriet W.

description: It's two days later and they're still sick. Damn. They beef work on cleaning things up, a call to the health dept may be in order.
author: Jessica O.

description: I had some pretty decent beef curry here and my friend had a bento box.  Definitely not the best food I've had, but the price is low enough that i was satisfied. The decor was simple but nice.
author: D Z.

description:
About average.
You'd think that there would be quality restaurants in Japantown but when I looked up places on Yelp, there were a ton of 3-star restaurants. Kinda pricey for average food. I prefer Kiki's on 9th between Lincoln and Irving.

I had the chicken teriyaki which tasted pleasant and tonkatsu that was also not bad.
Appreciated the amount of rice they give you, a little more than Kiki's usually gives. Decent service.

Overall, not a bad place to eat in Japantown but also not phenomenal.
author: Lauren L.

description: Ramen was bland, noodles overcooked.  Sushi was inedible.  Waitress was nice but service was otherwise non-existent.  Don't recommend with so many better options available nearby.
author: Joseph S.

description: I've been going to this place since I was a kid and my family lived in the Richmond District in the late 80's and its been awesome! BUT since the new management the quality went DOWN the drain! I hope they get it together soon! This is SF J-Town -expectation: HIGH!
author: augustus t.

description: I have been to this place 4 times now! However, the customer service is literally terrible. All the waitresses are really rude and don't respond to you if you ask for things. I've gone to this place multiple times because it's cheap, but on Sunday I went and ended up getting food poisoning. Will not be going there or bringing my friends there anymore. I would recommend checking out a different restaurant.
author: Victoria G.

description:
There are so many choices in J-Town but we decided to try this one and we weren't disappointed.

We had the California Bento and Katsu Curry. They were both good and the portions were worth the value.

The restaurant is split into two sections. The front has open tables and the back area has tables with high backs so you get the feel of having privacy. The waitresses were fast and no-nonsense. This isn't a place for interacting with the staff like some restaurants. It could have been that it was late (we went after a film we saw in the the Asian Film Festival) and they were ready to go home.

If in the area, would definitely try it again.
author: C R.

description:
Food was decent.

HORRIBLE SERVICE!  Our waitress stood around talking to other co-workers while we were waiting to order.  The waitress, after giving us our food didn't bother coming back to see if everything was ok or if we needed anything else.  Considering there were only three other customers, I was very unsatisfied.  She then later gave us the check for another table, TWICE!

I will not be coming back because of the horrible service.
author: Cedric F.

description:
Came here during lunch time before Wekfest. It was okay, it wasn't anything special really.

- Wait for the food took foreverrr. Everything came out at a different time too so by the time the last person got their food, the first was finished.
- The food was decent, price was okay.
- Service is decent, a bit slow. They seem to be short staffed or something.
- It's pretty small like most of the places in Japan Center.

Nothing really stood out about this place, I probably wouldn't go back. My friend says she goes here all the time and the food usually comes out right away. I think it might just be lunch time so if you come during then, prepared to wait!
author: Dan T.

description: The place to go to when I am in a Japan town SF. They always place a good portion of uni for their uni nigiri. That's the only thing I've ordered and spider roll. The taste of the spider roll was mediocre. Friendly staff.
author: Kosmo Z.

description:
As my girlfriend and I went to Japantown to do some shopping we got hungry so we decided to try this place.
First thing we noticed was the table was dirty from the previous customers and had not been cleaned.
Secondly it took the waitress a long time to get our orders.
Third the wait time for our food, I can understand it takes time to prep and cook things but this is ridiculous it took almost 20 mins for them to deliver our appetizer orders and when we asked the waitress for more water she said ok and walked away with a smile and totally forgot our request.
Upon arrival of the food I noticed that the rice on the sushi rolls were not out together very well and just fell apart when I picked it up with my chopsticks.
The tuna tasted fishy and it felt like they just recently defrosted it.
After this experience I will never dine here again terrible service and sub par food definitely not worth the money they are charging..
There are other restaurants in the mall much better than that place my advice stay away.
author: Paul H.

description:
After many years of passing Kashi Tsuru to dine at Benihana with family and being intrigued by their displays in the window, I finally had the opportunity this past Sunday during the Cherry Blossom Festival to eat here. 

Upon arrival, we noticed that there were people standing outside of the restaurant. My sister went inside and asked how long the wait would be. She told her it would be about 15 minutes, we agreed to the wait and stood outside, since their waiting area only held two (or three chairs). The walkway between Kushi Tsuru and Benihana is pretty narrow, so we had to make sure we were completely out of the way. 

After about ten minutes, my sister's name was called. The hostess either didn't look or wanted to wait, but she was quick to cross my sister's name off and get ready to call the next party up. We had to cross the sea of people just to get to the entrance of the restaurant. Fortunately, my sister caught her in time and told her that we were there. We were seated and given our menus. Every minute or so, the waitress came by to see if we were ready. I had never eat there before and wasn't sure if I wanted the udon, ramen or rolls. After the third time she visited our table, we were ready. I order california rolls (I wanted to order something "light" since I had already eaten an hour before) and my sister ordered the chicken katsu. 

The rolls were good, not amazing. I definitely wish I ordered udon or ramen. The chicken katsu was moist and delicious! Service was OK, it just seemed a little too fast-paced for my liking. I like going into an establishment and having an adequate amount of time to look over the menu, eat, and be able to talk with whomever I'm eating with. I don't want to feel rushed while I'm eating. But I guess this is just how they run the place. 

I would like to go back and try their udon and see if it compares to what I had in Japan. I just hope the next time my dining experience won't be as rushed as my first.
author: Ardella O.

description:
Tried Oyako don here, kinda disappointed..
not so much toppings on the rice.. the disproportion
of chicken and rice made tons of leftover of rice..
and the egg was little bit overcooked as well..
:-(
author: Yann M.

description: A day at Pika Pika with my boyfriend and we ended up here cause we were hungry. This place is ok, but I think we should have picked another sushi place since there are so many nearby. But oh well. Their portions are really small and do not match their prices - we ordered California roll, chicken katsu, and caterpillar roll. Not enough to fill us both up. There were like 4 pieces of really small chicken katsu and the Cali roll was small too. The caterpillar roll was ok but I've had better. I think this place just has jacked up prices because they're located in a popular area. Wouldn't come back simply because I can get better sushi for a better price that gets me full.
author: Celeste M.

description: We were having a hard time deciding which restaurant to go to in Japan Center.  So I was like whoever is validating our parking in the garage will be our lunch spot for today.  And Kushi Tsuru is our place!  A few other restaurants didn't offer validation.  We had California Rolls, which were delicious!!!!!  I also ordered a Katsu don.  I'm always afraid my pork is undercooked so I had to remind them, please fry my pork like crazy!  Which they did. Thanks:)My bf had the nabeyaki udon. His egg was a little overcooked so we requested another one and our server kindly had it replaced for us.  Second one came out just the way he likes it.  He was all smiles:)  We will definitely return.  Our server was really nice and food came out quick! Loved it! See you guys soon!:D
author: Betty L.

description:
After looking at 5 restaurants we finally settled for Kushi Tsuru. The place looked really small from the outside but when we walked inside - it looked a little bit more roomy. We ordered the tonkotsu miso ramen, beef udon and the tempura udon. We also had the San Francisco Fire appetizer. I really liked the San Francisco Fire app. It is a deep freid spicy tuna roll, seaweed salad, and tobiko served on a bed of lettuce with a spicy balsamic vinaigrette. The vinaigrette was delicious! It tasted really well with the lettuce and the tuna roll tasted good. 

I was less impressed with the tonkotsu miso ramen because it really did taste like the tonkotsu packaged ramen I can make at home. Nothing impressive. The beef udon wasn't as good as I had thought either. The soup flavoring was there but the meat wasn't seasoned. The tempura udon was a little disappointing. I think it makes more sense to put the tempura on the side rather than in the soup. By the time it got to our table the flour was soggy and falling off the shrimp. It was like putting soggy bread in soup. 

I love Japantown so if I ever come back I would want to go to the other restaurants and try them out before coming back here. 

~ happy eatings
author: Rosa C.

description: Saw a mouse run across the floor and into the kitchen here tonight. Two stars because the mouse was skinny.
author: Jonathan G.

description:
One of the more dependable places in Japantown.  You're never sure what you're going to get since all the plastic food everywhere basically looks the same, but this is one of the better places that we've actually bothered to give repeat business to.  They have above average katsudon, which is my dish of choice, and you usually don't have to wait for a table.

Recommended.
author: Chad H.

description: The best restaurant in that strip of restaurants in the Japantown mall in my opinion. I ordered the unagi donburi, and it was very filling. It came in a cute little box of rice with a huge slab of unagi on top. Also ordered the caterpillar roll which was pretty good. This is my go-to restaurant of choice in the mall.
author: Lily Z.

description: This place is inside restaurant row in Japan town. My wife and are in Japan town all the time but we typically never eat at any of the tourist places. At least our perception was this was a touristy place but as we sat in the restaurant i noticed they seemed to have long standing regulars who had been coming to this place for years. Every day at the same time and getting the same meals. the couple next to us had been coming their for at least ten years every day. The food was great. I enjoyed my salmon Teriyaki and crab and avocado rolls. my wife really enjoyed the tempura shrimp she got. We will come here again.
author: Sarmad N.

description:
I went here with friends while walking around Japantown. Looking for something other than sushi, I got the Kushi Bento while the others got Shoyu Ramen, Sukiyaki, Unagi with rice.

The bento was pretty good and a good value for about 10 bucks. It was filling for a dinner (I even left some extra rice) but aside from a tiny piece of unagi, the rest of the box were relatively inexpensive ingredients (iceberg lettuce, imitation crab, cucumber, tofu). The tofu was really well done with good soft texture, a crisp crust over a nice light sauce. I enjoyed it quite a bit.

The ramen looked relatively unremarkable, as did the sukiyaki and unagi, aside from the overall fresh ingredients and a sukiyaki loaded with beef. Overall, they're what you would expect in a mall establishment for food.
author: Newton L.

description: To start off it was boiling hot and stuffy inside, made the horible service we got more frustrating. The place is small and they weren't really busy, so it made no sense that they took almost an hour to take out order, and on top of that not give us everything we ordered and still make us pay for it.
author: Katherine S.

description: Ok, food was awesome here....BUT...i came here with my friends. I ordered the California Bento but I substituted the fried fish for more terriyaki while one of my friends ordered the same thing but just a regular California Bento without substitutions...normal and regular...after my friends and I got our food, we had to wait about 30 extra mins for my friend's normal California Bento to come...it took forever! I hate their service here, we needed a refill of our tea and been waiting more than 20 mins for it, they didnt take our old bowls of miso soup away. Just horrible. The food was good, but the service was horrible! I can have better food and BETTER service somewhere else! Enough said!
author: Claudia M.

description:
We came here after the preview tour of the Academy of Sciences. We ordered the Mango Deluxe Roll, the Spider Roll, and the Dragon Roll.

The service was friendly enough and the presentation was great, but I found the rolls to be fairly fishy tasting.

I don't think Thursday is the best day for sushi anywhere, but regardless, I found myself wanting to pick off or out most the fish, crab and eel, rather than deal with a less than fresh aftertaste.

I imagine this place may be better early on in the week, when they have fresher fish, espeically since the vegetables within each roll were all quite good, and the prices - reasonable.
author: Jessica T.

description: I was there twice and was not impressed. Average at best. Japan town tourist trap, you can get much better sushi if you walk 5 minutes from that place
author: Igor P.

description:
Have you ever come here at Christmastime when they have the white wire reindeer with the blinker lights and the heads that move up and down? Egad!...freaks me out every time.

Kushi Tsuru is the quiet eatery in the darkened hallway of Kintetsu Mall. No floating sushi here. No screaming, cleaver-wielding meat servers either. It's probably half the size of Mifune next door, and it certainly doesn't have the scope of plastic food replicas that Mifune has. I always thought it would be good for me to buy some of the plastic replicas, then bring them to a restaurant, display it on the table, and inform the waitress, "OK, have the chef make this." But somehow, I don't think it would go over well at Lucky Penny.

If you don't know, deep-fried food is their specialty. Gotta love that...though the sushi is very good here. No complaints at all. But I seem to order the $10 salmon teriyaki a lot since it is a pretty hefty portion for a Japanese restaurant. Sometimes I have a weakness for the beef and chicken kushiage, which is about $2 a skewer. It adds up if you don't watch out.

The service is always nice...though they aren't the quickest in J-Town. That's ok since it's usually pretty low-key here, and you may want to just hang. So if the speedy daggers of Benihana have you in a dither or the sight of raw fish on a toy-boat makes you seasick at Isobune, then you should give Kushi Tsuru a try.

FOOD - 4 stars...deep-fried...mmmm.. Homer Simpson would be happy here.
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...a bit lacking but the low-key vibe is nice.
SERVICE - 4 stars...really nice, a tad slow when the going gets tough
TOTAL - 4 stars...a fine Japanese eatery even if you're not a mouthy tourist who thinks you're in Chinatown.
author: Ed U.

description:
Mmm sushi n sashimi!

Great place in Japantown mall. The service was great, the sashimi was like butter, and the kushi bento had a lot of variety.  Their Rainbow roll was pretty good too. There are a ton of options for sushi in Japantown, so I'm sure they're all competing for business. Kushi Tsuru has definitely earned mine.
author: Lyndon M.

description:
My boyfriend and me went to that place Sunday night which is a big mistake. I ordered a miso ramen, the noodle is really dry feels like barely cooked.

That not what I hated, the waitress there is really rude. We ask them about all kind of dipping sauce which is which and she totally just grab my chopstick pointing and picking all my dishes in my bowl. And she act like totally not happy about me asking her questions at all. Then we called her over say since they have so many dipping sauce they probably should at least let us know which is for which, and she said she already told me that which she totally didn't. Then she start arguing with me.

All I want to say is that will be the last place on earth I'll go.
author: Hui L.

description: Terrible food, terrible service. It's the worst zaru soba I ever had. I've had many in my life, and this is by far the worst. I think the supermarket soba you make at home tastes better than this. I don't even know if you can serve such a dish. For the first time, I tried to send it back, cause I absolutely hated it. I spoke to the Japanese server in Japanese who said she never had it before and she said I guess it's just like that but sometimes the hardness may be different. I felt like there was no sense of urgency to fix the situation and she just walked away. ?!?!?! Then, my husband decides to eat the soba because he doesn't want to be "that" kind of customer. After he ate it, I told the other waitress and she was trying to say something along the lines that it's an acquired taste, as if I never had soba in my life. I said NO, no, no, THIS ONE tastes bad. We left 10% tip because my husband doesn't have the heart to stiff them, but really, I hope they see this review and step it up a notch. Sorry, we won't be back.
author: S L.

description:
Attended the "Tofu Festival" (I wanna get TOFU WASTED !!!) and we decided to grab a bite ... the restaurant mall/row in Japantown approaching from the Peace Plaza, first is "Osakaya" which is pretty good and exceptionally good for their takeout counter.  Then, "Mifune" which is my fallback for Tenzaru Soba which I had last night as a matter of fact.  And is quite good if you're in a noodle-y mood.

Then there is "Kushi Tsuru" and whilst the tempura was edible;  Was rather disappointed with the rest of the soba and sushi combo that was $10+.  The soba was a bit overcooked, so NOT al dente and likely previously prepared ... the nigiri that came with it was definitely previously prepared, the fish had died, likely of natural causes (old age), or maybe it was guppie suicide, in any case, I took one bite and that was all she wrote...
author: Terry A.

description:
Kushi Tsuru is bad.

Bad food (bring antibiotics), bad service.

Too many other great places in Japan town to eat.... Takara, Mifune,  Ino Sushi (but owners are old school and have an attitude)....
author: Matsuo U.

description:
Man, I just don't understand the curse of mediocrity that plagues Japantown restaurants. What's up with that?

My tonkatsu shoyu ramen came with:
- A METRIC TON of noodles (only thing they didn't skimp on)
- ONE paper thin slice of chashu
- ONE equally thin slice of fish cake
- Four pieces of bamboo shoot
- Three bean sprouts

Why so skimpy?? Croquettes were great though (not that you can mess up any kind of fried potato product), so if you must come here, order that.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
Small place, not very clean, has nothing special to offer in the grand scheme of things. This place and the places next to it are all very similar in terms of what they offer. 
I had the spicy tuna roll. The fish was not as fresh as it should have been, leading to a strange initial flavor. The restaurant itself was not clean and it was made worse by the fact that it was small. There were annoying little gnats flying everywhere at all times. The prices would have been okay if the quality of the food and the place was better than it was. The service was okay, nothing outstanding.
author: Idk A.

description:
Its hard to navigate the many many sushi places in the area and pick out the favorites. Kushi Tsuru was the place we chose since it was raining and we didn't want to leave the mall! They do have quick service and we only waited about 10 minutes for our sashimi and noodles to arrive at our table. 

The sashimi (9pc Sashimi Moriawase - Maguro, Hamachi, and Salmon) was very good and fresh. I felt like it was a nice sized portion and with some rice and miso it was a complete meal for me. My husband got the cold noodles with tempura and dipping sauce. He thought it was just ok and lacked flavor. The tempura batter was very thick and took away from the vegis in my opinion.

This is a good place for a quick bite if you want something simple.
author: Natalie N.

description:
We stopped at Kushi Tsuru because it was lunch time and every other place was incredibly busy! Kushi Tsuru was not as crowded so we went on in. I ordered the seaweed salad and a combination platter with tuna sashimi, and boyfriend ordered the ten-don. Both were quite good and totaled to about $25. We were given a pot of green tea which suited me just fine, as I drink a lot of green tea with meals, and hate asking for refills.

I wasn't too crazy about the service. The people there seemed very upset about working there and made us feel uneasy. We were promptly handed our check without asking, and definitely without thanking our patronage. 

One waitress also refused to create seating for a party until all persons arrived, which caused tension for the entire restaurant having to hear the complaints of the party who objected to her methods, and caused further uneasiness later on when the tables had to moved. All the drama interrupted the peaceful nature that one needs to enjoy eating a meal. We left promptly after eating. I don't think I'll come here again. Maybe I'll stop by if I'm broke and in town, because they truly are pretty cheap.
author: Tisha G.

description: The food was good. However, horrible service. We were extremely thirsty from walking around checking out vendors during the Cherry Blossom Festival so we asked for water and chugged down our glasses before we even ordered. I ordered the Tonkatsu Donburi and a side order of gyoza. Other orders on the table: Caterpillar Roll, Salmon Teriyaki, and Chicken Teriyaki. Feedback on those dishes from the friends was that they were OK only. Where was the refill on the water? We had to ask twice which was not cool. Maybe I'm just expecting too much. When the check came, we paid in cash. The cashier didn't bring us our change which was about $10. We were going to leave about $8 tip anyways so decided not to bother complaining about the $2 to pocket. But still... Really?!
author: Steven V.

description:
Tonkotsu Miso Ramen   ($8.95):  Seaweed, cha-shu, bamboo shoots, beansprout, ginger, onion, naruto fish cake, noodles in pork and miso broth
--------------------------------------------
Soothingly good broth,
But more noodles than protein.
It was a-okay.
--------------------------------------------
author: Jeanne L.

description:
Had the Chirashi Gozen Bento (Mini chirashi, assorted sashimi, deep fried flounder, grilled shrimp skewers, served with miso soup and rice) and it was pretty good. Had a lot of different things and was very filling, would def. get this again if I'm not feeling adventurous. My husband also got a bento, not sure what this one was called but it had some sashimi, tempura, rice, cooked salmon, veg, and two sushi rolls with a small bowl of miso soup. He liked it very much and said it was filling too. My friend had the tempura udon (Shrimp and vegetable tempura in broth) and said it was filling and good as well :) 

Place is a little small and had to wait a little bit till a table was free around lunch time on Saturday. Other wise i think the place was small and cute. Had a traditional feel to it and will go back again. :)
author: Alice L.

description:
The food was fair/ok. 
What really bothered/irked me was that there were flies at our table and I noticed the large group table had flies too. After I paid the check, I told the manager there were a lot of flies. I felt like he dismissed my comment and all he said was, 'eh, its hot, so there will be flies'. (This restaurant is indoors so I feel that they should make an effort to get rid of the flies. Its not very appetizing when you have to wave your hand throughout your meal to protect you food from flies landing on it)
author: Stacie W.

description: This place is located in the middle of Japan town in SF.  It's convenient when you're in the area for a little shopping.  I was starving and everything we ordered here was delicious.  The sukiyaki was great, with very aromatic meat and flavorful soup.  The tofu appetizer was also one of the better tasting one I've tried, with actual taste.  We ordered the hamachi kama (yellowtail cheek) but they were out of it so we subsituted with the salmon kama.  It wasn't bad, but I would have liked it better if it was hamachi.  Speedy service too.  One complaint I have is the lack of air conditioning in there.  But that is the issue with the whole mall and not just the restaurant.
author: Annie N.

description:
I was not impressed with the food here. Basic Japanese food that you could probably get at any of the other restaurants located in this plaza. Pretty much on par with Mifune right next door. 

When we first arrived, it felt like we entered a steam room -- it was boiling hot and beads of sweat were forming. Then all of a sudden the AC was turned on but that didn't last long. The owners need to do something about regulating the temperature in the restaurant.

I had the ten zaru (cold soba with tempura) which was ok. I recommend the agedashi tofu over the hiyayakko (cold tofu) appetizer.
author: Helen Y.

description:
Craving for broths, udon, ramen or Donburi bowls? These dishes are sometimes overlooked when eating Japanese food. Kushi Tsuru does it for me when it comes to brothy meals or stringy looking food. The restaurant's thick white slippery seductively slimy noodles of Zaru Udon or the Zaru Soba fills that late afternoon pang. Try the brothier Su Udon, if you want the volume of your slurps to disturb your fellow Gaijin dinner partner-- yum, or should I say, sluuuurph. 

If you're tired of eating the same-old maki rolls, then try this restaurant's ramen. There's a big selection of ramen to slurp loudly with. But...this restaurant does serve your standard tempura, rolls and other fine Japanese cuisine. For example, their Signature Maki rolls or their Temaki hand rolls and others. 

But once in a while, I urge all of you to slurp loudly and forcefully to show your appreciation for noodle and broth.
author: Reyz A.

description:
Their Tonkotsu Shoyu Ramen was dreadful, possibly the worst bowl of ramen I've eaten. 

Imagine having your normal shoyu broth: now add MSG powder, salt, more soysauce, and maybe salt water. That's how it tasted.  My two friends sampled a bit of it and confirmed its terrible taste.
author: howard l.

description:
So... something positive.  The service was quick once we were seated.

Yeah.  I almost dragged my husband out of the place before we were seated, as I watched the host literally toss two menus onto a table where people had been sitting for 5 minutes, because no one had brought them menus. This is not done at a Japanese restaurant of any merit.  He was yelling into the kitchen that they needed to clear tables, and made staff actually watch and wait for the table to get up and leave, so they could clean the table for someone. 

There was a table open, but they were understaffed, I hope.  Anyway, the waitress apologized, and seated us about 15 minutes after we put our names in at the desk. I should have realized that it wouldn't be good when I saw him toss the menus. I should have realized it wouldn't be good when I saw no line, when every other place in J-Town had a line.  I didn't follow my instincts fast enough.

My husband got the soba bento. His stomach had been acting wonky, and soba seemed safe.  The dipping sauce was fine, and the kappa maki was passable, but the soba was overcooked and soggy.  The nigiri sushi fish was poorly cut, and tasted like it had been defrosted in water. Just mushy and flavorless.  To their credit, he did not get food poisoning from their food.

I love karei karaage (fried flounder), so I got the Chirashi Gozen Bento.  The fish was WAY overcooked to the point that I only could find one or two bites that I could break off of the mass of fish.  The skewers were drowning in teriyaki sauce.  The mini chirashi had again, the soggy, fish. Maybe it was precut or something, but it was just poor quality.  The assorted sashimi was sitting on sushi rice.  UM... I'm pretty sure that if sashimi is sitting on sushi rice, it's called chirashi.  There were two bowl of chirashi on the same plate, one with awful vegetables in the rice, and one without.  If you have something on the menu, and you are trying to be authentic, bother to learn what you should be serving.  It was bad. I think one of the bowls of rice was SUPPOSED to be just plain rice, but no, it was sushi rice in both bowls.

By this point, I was so disgusted, not sure if I should bother trying to fix it at that moment because the wait staff didn't see anything weird about serving two large sections of rice in a bento box that I figured, it wasn't worth it.  I just paid and walked away, with 2/3rds of my meal uneaten.

Never again.
author: Erin O.

description: Came here spur of the moment with my roommate. Everything was great! Not too expensive and perfect serving sizes. Can't give it a full 5 stars until I try it again. Definitely coming back.
author: Mark T.

description:
We were walking around the mall in Japan town and were dying of hunger and we passed by Kushi once just to see what every store had to offer because most of the place had either a big menu out front or a display of what food they have inside. They place isn't too big but it wasn't crowed and we got a seat right away which is a plus. 

Most of us when we saw the Katsu Don in the window, we said that we would get it when we went inside to order. I'm not too sure if you can get water, but they do give you green tea for a drink.  When i got the bowl is was much bigger than what i would have expected it to be. Everything was really tasty. The katsu were really easy to cut apart with the spoon, although it wasn't crunchy, it was still tender which wasn't that bad at all. 
The price for this meal i would have thought to be pretty fair considering the amount that they give you.
author: Kent L.

description:
3 to 3 1/2 stars.

The food was definitely not bad, but far from amazing. But hey, a 10 dollar bento is a pretty damn good deal. I got the kushi bento. Seriously It was like 9.50. It came with some artificial crab, unagi over the rice, deep fried veggie skewers, miso soup, salad, agedashi tofu, and salad. The agedashi tofu was actually pretty good.. Better than many places ive eaten it at. The veggie skewers were good, so was the soup and salad dressing. The unagi sauce was was unusual, not like ive typically had it, and I thought adding artificial crab was weird. 

But all in all, if you're low on cash then this would be a good place for a meal.
author: Alison A.

description:
So we went here w/ a group of friends during SF's Japantown Cherry Blossom Festival. It was packed w/ ppl due to the festival. 

Food is a little on the pricier side but a couple of dollars, but well worth it. I shared the salted salmon w/ my gf [to save room for the food bazaar] and my friends got a bowl w/ noodles covered w/ noodles on top, bento box w/ soba noodles, nigiri & tempura & the other friends got noodles w/ a mix of seafood. All were very good, I loved how my friends noodles were chewy & sort of clumped together. Never had that kind of noodles that way before. Yummy. My gf's salted salmon was the best though, never had it that way also. It was grilled to perfection and salted in a way that you didn't have to add any soy sauce or teriyaki sauce to add flavor to it. It was unbelievably good. Ever since then me & my gf tasted that salmon we've been going around trying to find salmon just as good as the one we had here and one thats salted & grilled to perfection. 

I'd definitely go back here for the salmon. Only qualms are its pricey and small.

Oh yea funny thing was I finished earlier than the rest of my friends and me and a friend decided to explore the mall, the hostess/owner/manager? [one of them] saw us and I specifically told him that my friends are still eating and that we're just exploring the mall. Well when I got back from eating taiyaki, my friends told me that after I left the guy gave them a bill right away & had a nervous expression on his face. Hahaah shessh its not like we ran off on the bill. And my gf got a FAT ASS bruise on her calf because she was trying to get into the small cramped booths. RAWR it looks like my gf got shot w/ a paintball or bb the size of a golf ball. She hit the corner of the bench.

Well I enojoyed eating here and my time at Japantown SF.
author: Sofi P.

description:
I'm by no means a sushi expert so Japantown places can be a bit overwhelming.  So we popped in here after a movie w/our 11-year old.  Have to say it was A-OK.
Service was really good once we were seated after about a 10-minute wait.  Small, cozy space in the restaurant mall in Japantown.
Our son had the shrimp tempura appetizer, which was great.  Light and crispy with fresh shrimp.
We also had the cold udon, which was pretty good and the soba noodles, which again was okay.
The sushi was good - basic rock n' roll and dragon roll, but tasted fresh and price was average.

I'd come in again if in the area but wouldn't make a special trip.
author: amy b.

description:
Their rolls are good. The soft shell crab salad is delicious. 

Kushi Bento (the 10$ one) is also good, but you might wanna pay 2 bucks more for lunch set at nearby Osakaya (cos you can get more amount of protein - eels or beef. Here the only main protein is the eel.

Good service. I never have to ask for more tea.

Price is ok. Same level as their neighbors.
author: Sue R.

description: Very kid-friendly. Good food, nice staff, fair prices. I especially enjoyed their vegetable tempura and teriyaki salmon.
author: Michele G.

description:
Located inside Kintetsu Mall in Japantown, Kushi Tsuru is across from Benihana and next to a few other local Japanese restaurants that serve roughly the same type of food. I think what drew me to the restaurant was this shrimp tempura roll with tuna on top. 

We ordered a few items, some agadashi tofu, that shrimp tempura roll, this fried spicy tuna roll appetizer, and salmon collarbone.

The shrimp tempura roll (featured in one of the pictures on the blue plate) was overdosed with sauce. I could barely taste the fish with all that dressing and sauce they drenched on it. The salmon collarbone was overcooked and tasted fishy. The fried spicy tuna roll tasted a little dry. The only thing that tasted good was the agadashi tofu (but it's hard to mess up tofu)

Perhaps we didn't order the right things but what we ordered was pretty unmemorable. We expected more from a Japanese restaurant in Jtown.
author: Betty C.

description: Please don't waste your time here. I loooove Japanese food, but this restaurant is no good at all. The service is so bad. Had to call the waitress 5 times and she didn't even look at me. I asked them about the yelp offer, and the lady gave me attitude. Hmmm. The food? Yuck. Usually I love raw fish, but their raw tuna and yellowtail was not good. Maybe it was not fresh? Hm. Just please look for another Japanese place. Don't waste your money here like I did.
author: Alex M.

description: My husband and I chose this restaurant after walking for miles and being cold to the bone. The miso soup was exactly what we needed and very delicious. The sushi nigiris were large and the service was good. I loved the tea they served. Our bill was very affordable even though we had sake and beer. It's a small and low key place i would recommend for a quick stop. If you are looking for a more sophisticated experience I would recommend a different place.
author: Andrea M.

description:
With Sushi restaurants everywhere around Japantown it was really hard to find one sushi restaurant to settle on. We ended up picking Kushi Tsuru for a light early dinner.

We ended up getting the 9 PC Sashimi Moriawase ($15) as well as the Otoko Yama Roll ($13). 

I must admit that for a 9 piece Sashimi plate with Maguro, Hamachi and Salmon I was expecting a lot more than what we actually got. The sashimi itself was fresh but the servings were thin and small. I've had far bigger pieces of sashimi for a fraction of the price at other restaurants. Good taste, small plate.

The Otoko Yama roll, one of their signature rolls, was made up shrimp tempura, crab salad, asparagus topped with maguro tuna, salmon, tobiko roe and Kushi Tsuru sauce. Definitely a much better choice compared to the sashimi we got, which evened out our meal. 

I'd come back to try out their other signature rolls, leaving out the sashimi order.
author: Andrew S.

description: My mom and I ordered the chirashi and kushi bentos because they were $10 each. My mom is originally from Japan and she couldn't finished her bento. My 2 year old couldn't even eat the food and she eats EVERYTHING. We won't be going back again.
author: Chris H.

description:
After the Japanese Children's Day Festival at Japantown this past weekend, we had lunch at Kushi Tsuru. My daughter was in the mood for ramen, and Kushi Tsuru was the closest (and emptiest). Note - 'emptiest' should have been a sign about what was coming, but we still entered the restaurant for lunch.
Everything sounded great on the menu. However I soon found out that what you read is exactly what I got. So why the low rating? Well, I ordered the Tonkotsu ramen, at $8.95, the one with all the bells and whistles. "Seaweed, cha-shu, bamboo shoots, beansprout, ginger,onion, naruto fish cake, noodles in pork and miso broth".
