Ok now when they say cha-shu, get ready for a paper thin bit of pork. Half the size and 1/4 the thickness of the piece in the ramen at Suzu Noodle House (which I highly recommend!). The seaweed is decent, pretty much the only legit thing in the menu. Beansprout, I counted 5 beansprout. Yes, 5! Now is that even considered a handful? The rest of the items in the ramen description aren't much to write about.
So, yes, everything was in the ramen bowl that I ordered. Maybe I should have kept what I'd really be getting to my imagination. Realty is overrated right?
I think Kushi Tsuru is Chinese owned too! Chinese running a Japanese restaurant? That seems to be the norm in Japantown. If you want ramen and are looking for somewhere in SF Japantown, go to Suzu Noodle house instead.
author: Mark M.

description: My boyfriend and I went here last weekend and I was highly disappointed in the food. The service was decent, and we were seated right away. The side dishes such as the miso soup, rice, and salad were good, but the main entree dishes we had were horrible. My boyfriend ordered a sushi roll, and the vegetables inside it were overcooked. I ordered the vegetable tempura, which really should have been called "large plate of fried batter." I had to search through clumps of greasy batter to find vegetables, which were basically only carrots and squash. Also, there were hardly any vegetable pieces that were fried individually; they were all sort of clumped in one large mass. Needless to say, we will not be coming back and will try a different Japantown mall restaurant next time.
author: Molly I.

description:
The place was pretty empty... I had a craving for chicken teriyaki and seen the food model(? The plastic food in the window) of the CA bento box and it looked really good. It has 2 pieces of Ca roll, 3 pieces of tuna sashimi, chicken teriyaki, fried fish (random), salad and soup for like $9. What I got was super small portions: 4 pieces of chicken on top of the salad so my teriyaki sauce is now on the salad and mixed with the dressing, some weird pickled red thing on my rice, a tiny piece of fish drenched in tartar sauce.

The chicken was dried, the fish was over cooked, the CA roll was ok, the sashimi wasn't the best I had (and that's hard to mess up being that you're just cutting it) didn't touch the salad ( I hate cucumbers) the miso soup WAS good. Sadly, I prolly won't go back.

 I took my order to go so I only dealt with the guy at the register and he took my order quickly and was polite. The place was pretty empty though, so I guess he didn't have much else to distract him lol.

SN: They do validate!!
author: Jo C.

description: Great sushi, noodles, and teriyaki, and solid service. Our favorite spot at Japantown!
author: Masha B.

description:
Definitely an ok experience. It was not a poor one and it wasn't the greatest, it was just in the middle for Japanese places that I have been to.

I decided to try out the sushi and was wanting some variety, so I got the sushi in line. Of all the rolls that I had, I really enjoyed the california rolls the best, which means that the fish, while ok, could have been much better. 

The miso soup on the other hand, was great! 

It isn't too expensive and  service is alright. We got drinks quickly and seated quickly, soup came quickly, but the main dish felt like it took forever.
author: Lily K.

description: This is a solid 3. I had a ramen. It was good - but not nearly enough tonkatsu or chashu. The noodles tasted fresh. The California roll was good, but not the freshest. The tea was especially good. Cute little place, much like the other spots in Japantown.
author: Andrew K.

description:
I would definitely give this place 3 1/2 stars. 

Their prices are very reasonable especially for their bentos. Service is really quick and the waitresses are usually nice. I love how their menu has a variety of items rather than just sashimi and nigiri. 

I got the combination dinner with a choice of salmon teriyaki and salmon sashimi. It was alright, nothing too memorable but it did taste good. 

All in all, I will be back.
author: Fran N.

description:
I had a pretty interesting time here at Kushi Tsuru.

My friend and J-town regular suggested Kushi Tsuru because it was the restaurant he was most familiar with and a restaurant that probably wouldn't break my already depleted wallet.  Although I found the decor and atmosphere to be very pretty with its dark woods and goldenrod walls, I felt it was really stuffy inside.  Didn't help that they placed us in the back room too.

I'm not really quite sure what to say about the service.  They tried hard, but just not hard enough.  I had to ask twice for another napkin and chopstick set, but I'm glad they left the tea pot.  And also, the entrees didn't come out at the same time.  Most of the time, the staff was busy helping out other tables in the area even though we got seated first...don't know what's up with that.  

When our server finally came to take the order (after doing the other tables first, like I said before), I ordered some sort of chirashi combo which came with some skewers and a fried flounder.  The chirashi was so, so disappointing.  They had the nerve to serve me fake crab, and the sashimi selection wasn't even that great!  Just 4 measly slices or something, and NO salmon.  What. the. eff.

My friend's ten-zaru soba (tempura and soba combo) came some time later (of course I waited for his food to arrive!) and he had no complaints about the food, obviously.

Dessert was anmitsu and some red-bean with green tea ice cream.  All in all, it's just....fine.  Not too thrilled about the service.  I'm eager to try the other restaurants in J-town.
author: Ivana Y.

description:
Meh, I feel really bad giving this place a single star, but it was REALLY awful. I should have just stuck with my guns and waited out the line at Suzu. 

My sister and I arrived around 6:40 and waited for 15 minutes to order. I got the tonkotsu ramen and my sister got the "California bento." The bento came with 2 pieces of California roll, chicken teriyaki, fried fish, tuna sashimi, salad, miso soup, and rice. Sounds like a lot of food, right? And a pretty good deal at $9.50, too? Not so. Everything other than the soup and rice came on a single plate, all piled up together on top of a large portion of boring salad, instead of in a traditional bento box. I think this was a ploy for them to serve less food. Forget bang for buck at this place. The "fried fish" was literally a single, tiny piece of fried fish with a bit of tartar sauce on top. There were three mediocre pieces of tuna. They were mushy and had texture reminiscent of having been frozen and then defrosted. Most of the chicken teriyaki was fat or skin or bone. The salad actually tasted okay, drenched as it was in teriyaki sauce. My sister said the California rolls were pretty good too, too bad there were only two pieces. The miso soup and rice were okay, but God forbid they mess those up at a Japanese restaurant. Definitely not a good deal though.

My tonkotsu ramen was ridiculously BAD. The soup was the right milky color, but the taste was extremely salty and without depth of flavor. The broth was SO salty that I could not drink it at all. The toppings were practically nonexistent. I got a tiny one-inch square piece of sliced pork that was an end piece and mostly consisted of fat. It was nasty. There was one measly piece of nori, a tiny sprinkling of green onions, one tiny slice of fish cake, and maybe three pieces of pickled bamboo. Oh yeah, there was also some stubs of bean sprouts with a funny flavor. And don't get me started on the noodles. I've never had such nasty, limp ramen noodles. They were relatively thin, but had no bite in them at all. I would say that even 10 cent Top Ramen tastes better than the noodles they used. I will NEVER come back here. Even the basic ramen at Sapporo-Ya which featured boring soup and only spinach and green onions was better than this dreck.

This place is awful. Next time, I will make sure to pay attention to the lines. There's a reason why there is always a line outside Suzu and Mifune. Avoid this place.
author: Leslie H.

description:
The food quality was terrible. We ordered a kushi bento and a pork cutlet. Tempura was so bad they use the wrong flour, so they were not crispy at all. The pork cutlet rice was too saltly, and the egg over the cutlet was so over done! Food presentation was not attractive. waitress's serves was so so. 
NEVER GONNA COME BACK AGAIN!!:-S
author: Yuki l.

description: I ate here during my recent stay in Japan town. Their rolls are pretty good. The soba is of very good quality. The beef noodle soup was excellent. Probably not the top restaurant in japan town but they seem to have a steady stream of customers.
author: Manoj I.

description: Bad customer service. The miso soup was so salty we could not drink it. What made it worse was the udon soup I ordered was even more salty. I told the waitress that I could not eat the udon because it was super salty and she brought it into the kitchen and came back and told me the chef tasted it and it was fine. He must not have any taste buds. If it was fine, why would I leave the udon untouched if I had to pay for it? On top of that the sushi roll we ordered did not look anything like the picture in the menu.  All of the food was substandard and we will never come back again. The chef must have been asleep or has amnesia for the day. If I could rate this without a star, I would.
author: Marie O.

description: The boy was starting to get irritable with hunger as he seems to do about every four hours, so after an adventure trying to find parking, we entered the overwhelming but glorious restaurant mall of Japantown.  There wasn't a wait for this restaurant -- in fact, it was practically empty when we were seated, but it was bustling by the time our food arrived.  We ordered a dragon roll, spicy tuna roll, spider roll, and salmon nigiri.  As it became busier, I was a little disturbed that a few tables who arrived after us received their food first.  But when the sushi arrived, it was well worth the wait.  The rolls were good-sized, and presented attractively.  Our favourite was the dragon roll.  I have a pretty low tolerance for spicy food, but even the boy thought the tuna roll was exceptionally spicy.  Our total, with one drink and tip, was just over $50.
author: Sara C.

description:
Had a very good experience here. I really underestimated the restaurants in the Japan center (well, japan center in general).. since I always come back with a mediocre experience after visiting.

Ordered Nabeyaki udon, and wow ..it's really good. The udon was made to perfection, all the bits inside was delicious. They served in a large bowl ($10.50) and it's delicious.
Got Pink Lady sushi roll too, I think. It was $9, not bad. The taste, I mean.

I was so full, I only ate probably a couple of those sushi and 1/3 of my udon and left it.  And my friends were just staring at my bowl after finishing their food (they had bigger sized portions than I did...)  And they said to me, "Wait.. you will just leave your food here? You will not eat anymore?"
And I said, "...I'm full..."
*stare*

".....Why.. you want some?"

Without hesitation they grab my bowl from me and ate the rest of my food. Wow... I was shocked.

Seriously, I thought I usually eat much more than many *normal* sized people, especially girls, but .. I've been surpassed. I'm not complaining though.

For my part of the bill, I paid $15. Total was probably $55 with the others' portions.

It's kinda a long wait, around 30 minutes.  We came during the Cherry Blossom Festival though, unknowingly.
Saw a bunch of cosplayers...eh
author: Frankie W.

description:
FOOD:
1.) Cucumber salad = very simple salad .... ..... 
2.) Rainbow roll = hum... I forgot what it's like to eat out for sushi... I forget that most places don't have the freshest sashimi. This place reminded me.


SERVICE:
Not bad


ATMOSPHERE:
It's casual Japanesey. Lackluster. Really small. Tables a little too close to other tables where you will hear other people's private conversations and they will hear yours. I wouldn't mind so much if the food was awesome.
author: Angela L.

description: Dinner bento boxes here are delicious and great for picky eaters with a craving for more than just one flavor. It took a while for the side of beef I ordered to arrive but there was more than enough food on my plate for me to really care. The waitress kept apologizing for it anyway. Great service- very attentive, asked if we needed anything, and made sure our waters were always full. Would eat here again.
author: Alex M.

description:
After hopping around to all of the restaurants in Japan Center, Kushi Tsuru is without a doubt my favorite. I am a great lover of mango and sushi, and their Mango Paradise Roll is SO delicious. I also appreciate the luscious, simple spicy tuna roll.

I generally don't order the non-sushi dishes/dinners, so I can't speak for that part of the menu, but their tempura is legit and they always seem to use fresh veg (many places I've been use the tempura batter to camouflage veggies that are on their way out). 

The other reason I love this place above all of the others is because although it might not be the fanciest place, the food quality is consistent, servers have always been attentive, there are always tables (even during the Cherry Blossom Festival, when the mall is packed), and my husband and I can go in wearing jeans and not feel under-dressed.
author: Miquette T.

description: My mom wanted some authentic Japanese food since we made Japantown a pit stop on our trip to SF. There are many Japanese restaurants in the plaza, but we decided on Kushi Tsuru because of the presentation of the display outside. I ordered the seafood teppan and it came out sizzling on a stone plate. There was a combination of shrimp, fish, and scallops and the portion size was generous for the price. The fried fish was a bit salty, but overall the teppan was pretty standard and the experience was pleasant.
author: Sarah P.

description:
I went here two days in a row because I had some serious cravings for sushi. 

The first day I tried their miso ramen lunch special with sashimi over rice. The ramen was decent  (I enjoy spicy Korean ramen more ::gasp::) and the fish was fresh. Overall very reasonable priced, good service and left full. 

The next day I went back with another friend and we ordered the chicken yakatori - which was okay. Two different rolls which were very generous in size and tasty. The miso soup was nice with the extra veggies and a plate of edamame. Again everything was well priced and we left full. I also enjoy the vigilant tea service. 

The ambiance is relaxed and good for dates or a small group of friends. Some of the seats are really close together and after leaving full I couldn't figure out how I got into my seat in the first place.
author: Jade W.

description: Eh - just so so. Not great, and considering your options, probably better to go elsewhere. Portions are small and the food is mediocre.
author: Amazing L.

description:
Since Takara as closed, I came here instead. Honestly, the food selection in Japantown is pretty much the same, and most Yelp reviews don't really help in the selection process. I base this review on the freshness of the food, flavor, and waitstaff.  

This place actually has attentive waitstaff and great menu options, but the amount of flies and gnats was unappetizing. I spent more time trying to keep bugs off my sushi than I did enjoying it. I would rate this place 4 stars, but I'm scarred from the infestation.
author: Janet R.

description:
We went on a weekday, so there was not much of a wait and we were seated quickly. The g/f ordered ramen, and I ordered beef curry soba. We also had an order of dragon rolls, spicy ahi rolls, and some other roll (can't remember the name). 

The food came fairly quick, first the sushi, then the noodles. The rolls were very good, and their spicy ahi tasted a lot better than others I've had. My beef curry soba on the other hand, was ok, and it was boiling hot. I'm used to eating/tasting hot soup (especially while flavoring something I'm cooking), but the temperature of my curry soba was intensely high, and burnt my mouth and tongue. The flavor of it was ok, though I wish there was more curry flavor to it.
author: Jeff Y.

description:
It's really a 3.5, with an extra half star for the service.

Ive been coming here for years and for the price, I think it's the best spot for a quick lunch or dinner. The portions are just right and the staff is attentive. They are extremely nice, polite, and you never feel rushed. They serve you according to your own pace, which is nice. 

Although they do serve sushi, I dont think it's their specialty.. so if you're looking to add some sushi to your meal, order away.. but if you're having a sushi craving, I'd say to try elsewhere. The good thing about them being on the main strip of the mall is that you can just look in and see if you're like to eat here before going in (just dont be too rude about it.. because those who are eating can see you too.. doh)

Note: They offer validation for one hour of parking, so thats convenient if you're coming to the mall just to eat :)

*UPDATE: Changing from 3.5 to a full 4 star: they have updated the menu with a widened sushi selection.. we only tried a couple, but they sure were really good. I'll have to come back and try the sushi again!*
author: Jade T.

description:
For a restaurant located inside a tourist trap its just ok.

My friend and I didnt have to wait and I can assure you that if we did then I would have to hear her constant whining! =P j/k Steph

For the price point its quite reasonable.

We ordered and shared
1 large Asahi
1 large Sapporo
Combo bento : saute beef with onion, california roll, rice, salad, etc
Combo bento: chicken karage, grill salmon, rice salad, etc
1 miso ramen

service was prompt but they forgot our ramen.  When they realized their mistake we were done but my friend Steph felt bad and didnt want anyone to get in trouble.  I guess it was nice that it came out last otherwise it would've turned mushy.  

The food was okay. Everything was just ok.  I agree that the miso ramen sucked and was just salty.  I can confirm the small and thin slice of pork they place on top of the ramen.  Its embarrassing for $9.

Total was $51 with tax and tip.

I wished they asked if we parked in the garage because we would've loved it if they validated our parking. **weak**

They do appear understaffed with just one waitress, the owner, and some guy in the front.
author: Sun T.

description:
kushi tsuru : japanese food :: baja fresh : mexican food

It's...passable. It could even be construed as tasty if one were really that hungry. But whereas a baja fresh burrito would at least make you feel greasily full, a meal here might leave you feeling half-full, if not in stomach, then in heart. It's definitely run o' the mill and kinda does the job, but nothing special.

If you're lookin' for a decent meal, don't make the mistake of eating here because every other place in the Kintetsu mall is crowded and looks like a long wait. Come here if you're not that hungry, don't really care what you're eating, just need to get some food in that good ole tummy, and don't care what you pay for it.

Silly me, I didn't know the food was supposed to look AND taste like the displays in the window!

Service was good, but it wasn't very crowded. And now I know why. I feel like such a sucker.

At the end, the only roll I wanted was to roll out.
author: Christine Y.

description:
ok, service below average. we sit down for more than 10min. no one served us green tea. it is so not japanese tradition and culture. we had to ask for tea and beverage, this is the worst experience ever among all the japanese restaurants we had ever been to in the bay area. 

food, so so, same quality as all you can eat in some of the chinese buffets. portion is small. not worth of your $$$. 

if you want to have decent service and good jp food, not recommended for this place. if you just want to stuff your stomach. there are others in jp town. 

also they only validate $2 for the parking not 2 hours.
author: Ed J.

description:
I went here yesterday with my girlfriend and parents. Going to Japantown when my parents visit tends to be a standby when we reach an impasse on where to go. I pulled up Yelp and, as I suspected, most thing in Japantown were rated around the same so we picked this place after I saw their, "We have ramen!" poster outside. 

The server was fine, she was the sort who doesn't do any sort of over-smiley schlock which is fine with me. She was nice enough to mention the the sauce for soba normally has fish in it when my girlfriend ordered a veggie bento and asked if she wanted it without that. 

The biggest problem we had with Kushi Tsuru is the time it took for the food to come out. My dad ordered a teppan and yakitori. His teppan came out first followed by my ramen 5 minutes later. My mom's chirashi came another five minutes later along with the yakitori appetizer. About TWENTY minutes later my girlfriend's veggie bento was served. By this time we had foregone the "wait until everyone has their food" rule because everything was getting cold. It turns out the chefs had skipped the bento and focused on several other tables first. 

The veggie bento itself was a plile of soba noodles, cucumber maki and three pieces of fried tofu which was fairly underwhelming after having it built up for twenty minutes. My ramen was the same stuff I had bought at Nijiya a few days before with a small slice of pork and some bamboo shoots. The teppan and chirashi were good as far as I know. 

Perhaps we came on an off day.
author: Kyle K.

description: Very friendly people running this place.  Food was pretty good.  I would go back.
author: Gretchen B.

description: What can I say, J-town does not have the best Japanese food. It sucks because I want there to be good food there. I almost feel bad. Not really. The whole experience was pretty meh. The service was OK and the waitresses were friendly, but the food was blah. It was pretty much just sustenance. C'mon J-town, let's ramp up the standards and bring the food back to top-notch.
author: Michael S.

description: My husband and I love this place.  Our go to and the roll options are plenty but best dish is the sashimi rice with roe.  Delish!  We will always go back to this place for japanese food cravings.
author: Jeannie L.

description:
I've been disappointed in a number of restaurants in J-town, and this restaurant didn't change that impression. My friends had the urge to eat lunch in the city, and chose J-town as our rendevouz. Unfortunately, we chose this clean, crowded establishment as our hope to hitting the spot, but we were gravely disappointed. The service was actually pretty good, but the food was sub-par and the price was above average for what you got. The portions were probably large enough for a child, though it did look nice at least. I ordered one of the larger $15 bento specials, which I admit was decent in taste, but left me wanting to order another two bentos to get my fill. 

Nothing particularly special about this place at all. The food is whatevers, the portions are whatevers, and the miso is whatevers. Miso CANT be that hard to make good...for reals. Anyway, I'd give this place a pass. The two stars means you'll leave saying it wasn't worth it.
author: Dale C.

description:
I normally stop by this place when I am in Japan town for their sukiyaki. One day I wanted it "to go" and they gave us a tiny container of rice ( think one tiny scoop) with the sukiyaki. We asked for more rice because I can finish that container in 3 bites. The owner or manager  took the same container to the back and just tried to pack more rice into the same small container. He came back out and gave us the same container and I was shocked. I told him I wanted another container of rice and he wanted to charge $1.50 for more rice when the rice they wanted to give me was microscopic already. 

Even the waitress looked embarrassed. If you eat there you can have all the rice you want, but if you get it to go, you have to pay extra for more than 3 bites worth of rice. It wasn't even the money. It was the fact that they were being so cheap about it.

I'm never comming back again!
author: Anna T.

description: Loved their ramen noodle soup! We also ordered the dragon roll. For some reason ramen and sushi is a great combination! I wish the tea they give you was hotter. I also loved the crush red pepper on the table.
author: Kirsten L.

description: Not bad.  I got the 9pc Sashimi Moriawase and it tasted pretty fresh.  I know you'd probably expect more since it's "Japantown" and all, but it's a bit overpriced for what you get.  I tried a friend's sushi roll and another friend's tempura shrimp and veggies, but were satisfactory.  Don't think I'd come back.
author: Christopher L.

description:
Large Sopporo, Mango Paradise, Pink Lady, 2 Sake hand rolls, Spicy Tuna Roll and Cucumber Sunomono  - $55.85. The Mango Paradise was basically a California roll topped with tuna and a sweet kiwi sauce.  It was OK.  The salmon hand rolls were pretty good though and the cucumber sunomo was pleasant.

The server was on us like white on rice, ha!  She came back to us at least three times before we were actually ready to order.   It was my boyfriend's birthday dinner.  Low key per his request.  He wanted sushi.  Silly, we thought why not get Japanese food in Japan Town.  There were many sushi spots around but this one actually seemed to have two more unique rolls but they weren't anything great.  We came a long way for dinner for it being eh. Bummer.
author: Bernadette M.

description:
For years, this was one of the places in that row of restaurant inside the J-Town that I had not considered going to. The reason was that I had negative impression of the service. One time I came with my friend and we got so mad at the server's uncaring attitude we almost decided to leave no tip. Another time I was with somebody else and at the end of the meal the waitress acted lime she wanted to hurry, pay our bill, and go even though there was no lime waiting for a table.

Years have passed and I decided to give this place another chance. The guy host was quite pleasant, and I have to say this time I thought the waitress was overall pretty good. She even asked if I was okay and needed water when I had something go down the wrong tube and started coughing. The chirashi I ordered was okay, thought the rice could have been tastier.

Okay, at least I can give them a decent rating and for now forget the past negative impressions.
author: H K.

description:
Monday is not a good day to eat Japanese food, as many restaurants are closed.  Monday is also not a good day to explore Japantown, for the same reason.

On a recent excursion to J-town, we did not know this.  My favorite spots were all closed, so our friend suggested Kushi Tsuru.  I ordered an order of hamachi nigiri (pretty good) and a nabeyaki udon.  For the most part, decent service and good food.  I was happy to have Japanese food, but Kushi Tsuru is definitely not going to be one of my favorite spots any time soon.  Since I come to J-town so rarely and since I have other restaurants that I like here, I doubt that I will be back.
author: Patty W.

description: As far as food is concern, it was an okay place to eat at if you aren't too hungry. I ordered the unagi bowl and it wasn't too bad. It was the spicy tuna roll that I questioned a bit. My significant other had to raise his hand for a while until we actually got the attention of a waitress to give us our check.
author: Michelle H.

description:
I've had much better.

At least I have now eaten at a restaurant in the mall so I don't need to wonder what they're like.  I wished I could have gone to Benihana instead.  

Got the salmon teppan combo.  Bland.  California tobiko roll bland.  

Service was nice and wait was short but it's a very very mediocre place.  

Didn't know they validated parking.
author: Mrs F.

description:
Came here to satisfy a sashimi craving. It's conveniently located on "restaurant row" AKA the row of amazing restaurants located in the Japan center mall-ish thing in Japantown SF. Came around lunch time, and only had to wait 10 minutes or so before we were seated -- be careful not to come when it's too busy though, because the restaurant itself doesn't have such a large capacity. 

About the food: I'd say it's just alright. I'm not a sushi/sashimi/japanese food expert by any means, but I could definitely tell that the sashimi from this place wasn't the best. I ordered the 9 piece sashimi moriawase, which was 3 pcs. of three types of fish (salmon, tuna, and mackerel, I believe). The food itself was...mehhhh. The fish didn't taste the freshest; the color of the fish was very telling. I'd say I'd give the food a 3-3.5/5 stars. 

The price wasn't great though, at least not for the sashimi. It was $15 dollars for the sashimi moriawase, which didn't come with any rice, miso soup, or salad, as I've seen other restaurants do. Maybe I would have forgiven the absence of rice/miso/salad if the fish were fresher and more delicious, but alas, that was definitely not the case. What's weird is my mother ordered the California bento (2 pc. california roll, 3 pc. tuna sashimi, teriyaki, rice, and salad) which was $10, and my grandmother ordered the Tori udon, which was $8.00. They both seemed to get a significant amount of food for much less than what I paid for my sashimi. This would *seem* to suggest that the fish would be extremely fresh and aamzing -- definitely not the case. 

Overall, I'd say this place didn't meet my expectations. I paid a pretty penny for pretty average fish. The udon was apparently pretty good, so I'd recommend that over the sashimi. Ultimately, restaurant row is fullllllll of sooooo many choices for good Japanese eats. Look elsewhere (try Mifune).
author: Weian W.

description:
One of the cheaper restaurants in the mall
Came  here because the display looked tasty and the prices were reasonable, we were super hungry.
I ordered the beef ribs udon, but didn't say anything when just regular beef udon came to me, I was too hungry and just ate it.
There was too little beef in it, but a lot of soup.
Service was alright and the tables are nice and roomy.
author: Aaron C.

description:
I was going to Ichiban Kan in Japan Town to pick up a few household items. It was around lunch time and I was in the mood for a Japanese lunch. When I go to J Town, I have a tendency to go to the same restaurants. I decided to be adventurous and try a new place! 

Kushi Tsuru is one of the smaller eating establishments in the plaza at Japan Town. We arrived around 1pm and there was a 10 minute wait. Not bad for a weekend. 

I ordered the California Bento Special for $9.50. It came with chicken teriyaki, tuna sashimi, deep fried fish, California roll, salad, miso soup and rice. Everything was fresh and tasty. My friend ordered the Soba special and he said it was tasty too. The portions were good, the service was okay. The waitresses weren't overly friendly but that's okay.

They have an assortment of sushi (nigiri, temaki and maki).  The prices range from $2.50 to $10. They also have sashimi, donburi, udon and a wide array of combination meals and nabemono (one pot dishes). There was no special unch menu.

Parking is plentiful in the Japan Town parking garage.
author: Mari I.

description: Wife's ramen and daughter #1's udon seemed okay.  Daughter #2's avo-kyu maki came on a dirty plate accompanied by water with stuff floating in it.  My "bento" was about as bad as it gets in Japanese restaurants that cater to tourists.  Will not be returning.  Maybe my wife will.
author: Tom O.

description: Worlds longest wait to seat 4 people (1hr). Once seated the service is good and the food is even better. Its really small, not sure what the capacity is but there couldn't be more then 30 tables, mostly for couple dining. Not a private kind of place but if your on a budget, this is a good place. Benihana is literally 10 feet from this place so the food has to be delicious to keep people coming back. A lot of people had to-go orders which made a lot of sense because its not worth a wait any longer then 5 minutes. Close to my hotel and for a price you can't beat.
author: Jason G.

description: Japantown for some reason has the worst sushi in San Francisco. I thought the Pink Lady is Kushi Tsuru's best sushi and even that is just okay. For $13 + tax + tip, for sushi you can do better. I recommend going to Sushi Boom at Fillmore if you're in japantown. It's a little hole in wall-ish but the sushi is cheaper and better.
author: Ernie C.

description: I've been going here for years. As far as the food goes, it is excellent. I Love the sushi, and the tempura. The soups and meats leave something to be desired, but overall, the food quality is excellent.
author: Ron Z.

description: One day I was craving Ton-katsu Curry.  Where's Curry House when you need it?  Well since SF does not have Curry House, I walked over to Japan Town to get lunch.  While many of the locations in the Japan Town complex are not particularly stellar (with the exception of Sophie's and Suzu Ramen), they serve a purpose.  The purpose of going to Kushi was to get a quick meal for a decent price.  Three stars.
author: Shad B.

description:
We were walking thru Jtown and I spotted their posterboards touting their new ramen bowls. We decided to take the plunge. I ordered a Miso Ramen and my lady had a Dragon Roll. 

The ramen came out. Only one piece of chashu but a decent amount of ramen. Still didn't taste like real Japanese ramen to me.

The dragon roll was good according to the gf. 

Ended up having an upset stomach afterwards.
author: Alan Y.

description:
The food here is reminiscent of Yoshinoya/Happi House. The portions are generous, though. I wouldn't even TOUCH the sushi or ramen here; since you're already in J-Town theres much more better dining options than eating at the yuppie/tourist places, i.e Why go to Chinatown to eat at Panda Express?

It's said that you can judge a place by the amount of that cuisine's country people inside; you'll never see Japanese people in here! They're always at Suzu for ramen and for curry they're at the joint on the bridge, or Izumiya for okonomiyaki (which I feel went downhill compared to how it used to be).
author: Yodo S.

description: Average Japanese food. Nothing bad but nothing extraordinary.Fair prices with OK service.Had higher expectations since we were in Japan Town.
author: TED P.

description:
I've tried many places for Donburi with chicken and scrabbled eggs. From Sushi Maru to Gombei to Sushi Kai to various places, this place has the best Oyako Donburi EVER!
My boyfriend says their bathroom is as big as a bathroom on an airplane.
I liked their staff, atmosphere and the food. It was a good place to eat since we were in Japantown SF. I'd come back again.
author: Janeth B.

description: Fairly priced restaurant with nicely arranged dishes. The service was average, but the food was pretty good. Nice, quaint atmosphere. Salads have a little too much sauce!
author: Edward G.

description:
Though Kushi Tsuru seemed to have the most varied selection of rolls, the final products left a little to be desired.

The mango roll was only a certainty with the kiwi sauce, and most of the other rolls lacked a definitive taste.

I'd be willing to visit again, and would give 3.5 stars if it were possible, but since I'm restricted to whole numbers, I'll round down due to diminished quality of service.
author: Phil R.

description:
Too long of a wait, both for food and to be seated, but then again it IS lunch time. Our waitress seated us near a family with an obnoxious child who wouldn't stop screaming. She could've asked the family to try and calm the child down or at least apologized to us for the noise. I was dissapointed with my meal, I didn't ask for a FOREST of greens. You guys could've at least given me a little more chicken terriyaki.

After finishing my meal, my family and I had agreed to split up the check by 3 (my bro and I paying by seperate cards and cash for the rest). What was the hold up with this? Does it really take 10-20 minutes to swipe a couple of credit cards? There was way too much time wasted here waiting for ANYTHING.

I'm usually a patient person, but jeeze, these guys need to step it up with the speed.
author: Jay A.

description: I like going here. It's a quiet nice sushi place with decent quality food.
author: Rebecca C.

description: I always order the same thing when I come here- the tempura bento box with the salmon sashimi. Every time I've had it I'm always very pleased. The tempura is very crunchy without too much oil and the salmon tastes fresh. I know the amount of food can appear to not be too much but I'm always satisfied. (I need to say though, I can eat my fair share of food for my size.) My dad gets some kind of grilled steak and that is always cooked very well- the best I've seen and had from any other sushi place. Seating usually isn't a problem but then again I've always gone for lunch. It might be because I'm intimidated of driving to and parking in the city so it's a once in a while thing, but this is one of my favorite Japanese restaurants.
author: Krizelda M.

description: We needed a late dinner for our family of 6 -- which includes 4 teenagers -- and got out the door for $85 with tip included!  At 8:30 PM, there was no wait (they close at 9) and service was good.  Our daughters loved their ramen bowls (one got miso ramen, one got shoyu ramen), and one son got a sushi sampler with miso soup ("sushi in line")  and the other had beef curry which he said reminded  him of the curry our Asian nanny makes.  The kids were delighted with their noodles.  The cucumber salad looked good, tasted average.  The yellowtail sushi was excellent, and the green tea was wonderful.  My daughter complimented the tea several times.  The menu is huge and has something for everyone.   Everything was good; nothing was to die for but Kushi Tsuru is a  great option for families with hungry kids who like Japanese food.
author: Chamomile T.

description:
Came in here with some friends because there was no line. That's usually a bad sign, but I didn't really find it to be the case here. The restaurant was much cleaner than some of the neighboring spots and the service was attentive but not annoying. 

I got the tempura udon cause I was cold and it came at a fairly reasonable price for this area. I ate it, it tasted okay, but for some reason I didn't feel so great afterwards. Nothing major, just a "general feeling of malaise" as my mother would say. Hmm. Maybe it was the fact that I hadn't eaten all day? Not sure.

At any rate, the rest of the people in my party got these amazing looking dishes that included dessert and the fish was, I'm told, pretty good. Nobody else had a complaint, but they weren't singing praises either...hence the 3 stars. 

Oh, and they validate parking! Each of the drivers in my party got one hour so that was nice.
author: Katies F.

description:
2.5 stars... at BEST!

came here for lunch with my friend because i was SO craving for nabe yaki udon... and unfortunately, suzu's line was out the door! seriously... had like 10 people ahead of us... and u know how small suzu is! 

came here as their fake food looks good and the restuarnt has a strong japanese food smell... so i figured, it's gonna be good... NOPE.

the nabe yaki udon ($10bucks) was not the best that i had at all... the egg, which is suppose to be poached... looked like a fried egg that were individually cooked with a egg pan... the only veggies in the pot were carrots and a few sprigs of green onion and one shitake mushroom... dissapointed!  where's the napa cabbage?? I asked and they said they dont have any... wth! 

the california roll was decent.  rice was soft and avocado was fresh... that was the saving grace... 

ugh...
author: Kelly H.

description: While visiting the city, my party of 3 decided last minute to eat here. There was a little bit of a wait...15 mins but it was a Saturday evening and a wait was to be expected. From the reviews I've read on here...it's pretty mixed. The owner is very nice and pleasant...compared to the previous night I had at another Japanese restaurant. The menu has a lot of options, even veggie options and the price is right. For my party of 3, dinner was $42. Which I think, in the city is a steal! We ordered the California Shiitaki appetizer and my daughter and I really liked it...no complaints there. I ordered the Chirashi Gozen Bento...awesome and HUGE amount of food. The sashimi was fresh and yummy, the fried fish delish, the grilled veggies and teri steak - YUM. I shared my food with my guests since it was so large. My daughter ordered the Shoyu Ramen which she finished up to the the last slurp. She was very satisfied after that bowl of yumminess. My friend ordered the combination plate of salmon and a roll...I think? He ate it so fast I don't even remember what he ordered! I wasn't expecting the place to be that great, it being in Japantown's touristy part...but it was a great surprise. I'll definitely be back for lunch next time I'm in town. :D
author: Jenn H.

description: we ended up choosing this place after looking around because d price is cheaper n d wait for a table is shorter. d waitstaff didn't acknowledge us n we waited 20 mins to get seated. I ordered d gyoza, it was ok. ordered seafood teppan with soup, salad n rice. d salad was ok, soup was barely warm, seafood was overcooked; d oysters in my plate were pretty weird. d waitstaff took to long to ask for our orders, she never gave us d fork that we've requested. would never go back to this place, especially if you have a number of restaurants to choose from
author: Learnee L.

description: Ordered a miso ramen n salmon skin roll for lunch.  The restaurant was 70% full.  Took em good 25 min to bring the food to our table.  The ramen has 1 thin slice of pork n 1 slice of naruto fish cake.  Normally at a ramen restaurant u get 3 or so piece of meat. If u r a meat eater u will leave very disappointed.
author: Peter W.

description: Okay place, decent prices. I like that they 've changed the menu, and that there's a vegetarian section added on. I came in here earlier this week and had the cold tofu with dipping sauce, and vegetarian soba with seaweed broth and it was filling and healthy. I paid $14 including tip, which is not bad at all. Will be here again when I need to eat, but it's not the kind of place I reserve for a special occasion.
author: Shaf K.

description:
Out of all the places to eat in the Japanese mall, I always end up in Kushitsuru inside the Kintetsu buliding (middle). 

The line here can literally be out the door  as deep as maybe 6 - 7 heads. On a terribly busy day like weekends it'll be longer coz everyone wants to sit and satiate their appetite here.

I hate the cramped feeling you get but they are very accommodating and each booth can sit 6 people - in standard Asian sizing. Which means if you're a huge football player, you'll probably want one side just for yourself. 

I recommend ordering from the combination section coz you get more bang for your buck @ $11.95. You can order two things as your entree and they all come with rice and miso soup. I like the yaki-niku and salmon sashimi combo OR get the salmon teriyaki with salmon sashimi for some fish on fish love. 

You definitely can't go wrong with chicken karaage, edamame and gyoza for your appetizer. The edamame here isn't dry and salted just right. Yuuuum! 

P.S. On the bottom of the receipt it says "PLEASE PAY YOUR SERVER!" so don't be cheap on them hahaha!
author: Jaye C.

description:
Cute little place in the shopping center. Nice and dim lit. The sushi is decent. I had the Pink Lady, which was alright. I think the tuna could have had a little bit more flavor.
The service is okay. The waitress re-filled my water pretty sloppily but alls good.

They really need to fix their bathroom area though. Holyyyy. So you open a door which brings you sort of to a hallway where the bathrooms are and aghhh that area stank. It stank real bad. The bathroom is extremely small and cramped and gross. Just a warning.
author: Megan C.

description:
I've actually eaten at Kushi Tsuru many times, and we chose to come here again one morning when we were starved for lunch and Japanese food. Since all of the restaurants in the Japantown strip mall are around the same, we decided to go to Kushi Tsuru. I think what makes Kushi Tsuru stand out a  little more than the rest of the restaurants right next door (Mifune, etc.), is the better service and cleaner/nicer interior decor.

Our server here was very nice and she kept joking around that we would not be able to finish our orders. Between 4 of us, we ordered 5 entrees and 3 appetizers... all of the food was a little above average. I had the Agedashi Tofu, which is my favorite appetizer... It's friend tofu put in a bowl of (tempura?) sauce. And for my entree, I had the Teryaki Salmon which came with vegetable tempura. All of my food was really good, and my friends all seemed to enjoy it too. Our bill came out to $80 which wasn't too bad considering the amount of food we had ordered. 

I personally enjoy coming to Kushi Tsuru when I want Japanese food. It's not often that I want Japanese food, since I'm more of a sushi lover, but the food here is good, and the service is also really good.
author: Tiffany K.

description:
Decent place to go for lunch.   I haven't tried their sushi yet, only had their combo with chicken teriyaki and shrimp tempura.    I'll try the sashimi next time.   

Overall, it's clean and service was good.   Can't really complain about anything here.
author: Jeff H.

description:
Just because the plastic food on display outside of a Japanese restaurant looks good, doesn't mean the food inside is!!=P

Ordered a sushi (nigiri) bento.. definitely overpriced for the amount and quality of food!!  For paying $12+, I was not full at all.. not to mention it tasted like a whole lot of disappointment.  This was the first time I ever had stale California roll.. you could really tell it had been sitting around because the rice was hard on the exterior. 

Ew ew ew, would not recommend.  What is it with Japantown and extremely mediocre Japanese food?
author: Jennie L.

description:
We ordered the Katsu curry rice and the chicken donburi. The curry was watery and had a few potatoes and carrots. The katsu was decent, but the dish as a whole was not worth the $9 we paid for it. 

As for the chicken donburi, the chicken was all low-quality and dark meat. There was some egg, but the dish as a whole was not very tasty, and it consisted of mostly rice.

We won't be back and hope that the management would take note to try to improve the taste, as well as the pricing of the food.
author: Brentissa S.

description:
This is my favourite restaurant in Japan Town, and only for one thing: salmon teriyaki teishoku. Plus, their miso soup is the tastiest I've ever had; I wish I had a big pot of it at home that magically refilled itself so I could have it every single day. And their gyozas? Hot and crispy and deliciousssss.

They are also the only Japanese restaurant I know of that leaves the teapot with you at your table, so that you can refill your cups at your leisure. Why is this not a common practice at all Japanese restaurants??? It's a travesty I tell ya. 

The service is so-so. It depends on who you get and if the place is really busy or not. If you're a regular, feel free to special order stuff; they'll accommodate you. 

I would say if you want sushi, try another place because although I don't like sushi myself, I've seen what they offer and it just looks small and sickly to me. Also, don't get the shabu shabu. It's not the real thing where you get a separate pot of boiling water to cook the meat in...it all comes in a big cereamic bowl, cooked in a broth of some sort. A friend got it one time and was really disappointed it wasn't an actual shabu shabu experience.
author: M S.

description:
A group of us went to Kushi Tsuru for lunch.  We were quick in finding a place while attending an all-day seminar at the Hotel Kabuki.

I had the Chirashi Delux and my friends both had the Kakiage Udon.  The Chirashi Delux is assorted sashimi served over sushi rice.  It was a little bland but it tasted alright -- because I was famished it was good at the time.   The Kakiage Udon is udon soup with deep fried vegetables served on the side.  The udon bowl was large with a lot of noodles and the veggies were large in portion.

We were finished with lunch within 45 minutes, heading quickly back to the seminar.   Service is friendly and efficient.  Kushi Tsuru is good Japanese for eating on the run!
author: Janet H.

description:
This was my favorite sushi restaurant in the world for almost 10 years! This nondescript sushi joint in SF Japantown, 

Excellent food, excellent service, great traditional menu, and always quick!  I've tried almost every place in Japantown, almost every place in SF, and this one is by far the very best. It's a locals secret. :)  

Great food, and great prices. You can't beat it in SF.

Looking for the right one? It's right across the hall from Benihanna.
author: Rachelle G.

description:
My family's standard choice for Japantown visits. 

Very standard "teishoku" style fare in a slightly cramped environment. Typically, Americanized sets (usually labeled as bento) tend to consist of teriyaki and California roll but Tsuru has more typical Japanese options such as kushiyaki (breaded skewers) sashimi, tempura, tsunemono, zaru soba, and so on.
author: David P.

description:
Weaving through all those tourist trap restaurants in J-Town, you can find a handful of decent Japanese restaurants and Kushi Tsuru is one of them.  Ironically situated right across from Benihanna, their tight cramp location is is worth the occasional wait for their fair priced dishes and decent tasting sushi rolls.  They have number of different dishes, soups and bento options, so try to stay focused when ordering.  

The Kushi Bento is a good way to try a number of items in one shot.  The sashimi isn't the best, but it is good enough not to get sick.   Sushi roll fans, might want to give the Otoko Ya Roll a shot.  It has real crab, asparagus, covered with salmon and tuna sashimi, drissled with different sauces and topped with three different kinds of roe.  Along with the quick and friendly service, Kushi Tsuru is not a bad choice when seeking Japanese cuisine.
author: Jason A.

description:
Of the four restaurants that make up the little eatery "tunnel" in Kintetsu Mall, Kushi Tsuru is adequately average to say the least. It's a bit smaller than Mifune, and it never seems all that busy, but in a way I can see why now that I've finally eaten here.

The menu seemed fairly limited, with the standard sushi, noodle, and donburi items most other places have, with average prices ($8-$10/dish). The food itself was tasty and made well enough, although it came out somewhat slow considering how little business there was when I went. Really, when I think about it, there isn't much on the menu to differentiate Kushi Tsuru from any other place in Japantown, and it certainly wasn't good enough to make me a regular when compared to Mifune's excellent dishes.

Service was nice and polite, though somewhat pervasive at times (probably because it was slow), though it wasn't a huge deal. The place itself felt a bit cramped because of how small it is - definitely not a good place for a huge group of five or more - and a bit exposed since it sits right at the end of the tunnel leading towards Kinokuniya. Needless to say, I was a bit uncomfortable.

All in all, Kushi Tsuru is decent, but with the sheer amount of options available to you why settle for less? If you're looking to try all the restaurants it's not a bad one, but you're better off going next door. Sorry, Kushi!
author: Will C.

description:
A good friend of mines took me here years ago. I come back here from time to time, probably 3 times a year. It's reasonably priced, clean (except for the bathrooms - see below), cute booths, and decent pork katsu don. My friend had the KB Special and she enjoyed the variety. The restaurant is small so hearing others conversations are pretty easy.

One downside, is the nasty bathroom that stinks. Waiting in the hallway to use it, really smelled bad that I had to cover my nose as I waited to use the restroom.

I don't get out to Japantown often enough to try other restaurants and check out all the spots.
author: M M.

description: Fantastic portions, food is good--not great. Noodles slightly overcooked. We had a Chinese waitress who was constantly exasperated and unfriendly (she "huffed" and rolled her eyes when the wrong dish was brought to our table and we had to point it out to her) but the hostess at the door was kind and charming. At our table we had the nabeyaki soba, chashu ramen and a veggie tempura udon. Soup was served hot but the complimentary green tea was bit watered down.
author: Cinna M.

description: Decided to give this place a try since one of my Japantown favorites is closed on weekdays.  I ordered the vegetarian combo (agedashi tofu, zaru soba, cucumber roll) and one hamachi nigiri.  The agedashi tofu was good but everything else wasn't quite right.  The zaru soba was overcooked and the green onion topping looked like it had been sitting out for days (all dried out.)  The nori on the cucumber roll was chewy and the rice seasoning was off balance.  The worst was the hamachi nigiri which tasted pickled rather than fresh.  I took one bit and left the rest on the plate.  Won't be returning to this place.
author: Suzanne G.

description:
I had to fast after my dinner on the previous night so I was particularly hungry on this afternoon.  I peered through the windows and OsakaYa and Mifune were quite packed during the lunchtime hour.  There were several empty booths at Kushi Tsuru so I decided to give this restaurant a try.

A waitress and one of the kitchen staff speaks Cantonese here, but aside from that detail the service here is nothing noteworthy.  Instead of studying the menu in detail I ordered something that I am familiar with, chicken teriyaki and California rolls.  A pot of hot green tea arrives along with a bowl of miso.  I took one sip of the miso, but I found it quite too salty.  A small dish of what looked like cole slaw followed.  I assumed it was pickled vegetables of some sort.  I took a small sample, and that was enough as the vegetables were quite salty as well.  I guess I wasn't that hungry after all.  It's a bit of a wait before my food arrives, and I notice right away that the portions are small.  One flattened grilled chicken thigh with skin intact charred on one end, but nicely grilled on the other served on a lettuce leaf and drowned in teriyaki sauce.  Except for the charred parts it tasted pretty good.  The California roll was tasty too, but it was difficult to figure out whether I was eating imitation crab or real crab since the filling was minced finely accompanied only by a chunk of slightly-browning avocado.  The ginger that was served to the side of the California roll had an unpleasant, kept-too-long-in-the-jar-type of taste to it.  Neither waitress stopped to ask if everything was okay during any point of the meal.  My rating shows three stars, but maybe two and three quarters should be sufficient.
author: Wilhelm Y.

description:
My eyes were bigger than my stomach or rather the food descriptions incited me to order more than I needed.

Started with the Fried Tuna Roll Salad. It had a better name but I can't remember. But essentially it is a salad with deep fried spicy tuna rolls, with a generous toss of wakame - or seaweed. It was a nice take on a salad, but tasted just ok.

Tried the specialty roll - Otoko yama - which was a California roll topped with salmon and tuna and black and green roe. Very pretty presentation, 8 big sizeable pieces - all for $12. This I liked a lot. Great tastes and condiment pairings.

Here's where we ordered too much - also had the Nabeyaki noodles $11. It was a cold evening so I wanted something warm. It comes in a big clay pot filled with tofu, salmon, shrimp and various seafood, noodles and veggies. The fish was overcooked but the broth was good.

This is a simple place to have dinner. I would go back and try other specialty rolls.
author: Cindy W.

description:
When I was a mere child I remember my mom taking me here one a week. This restaurant was very different back then. The hostess and waitresses wore these beautiful Kimono's and had their hair up in Chopsticks. Very formal looking actually. I especially loved how they remembered who my mother and I were and would greet us with smiles and warmth. We'd always sit in a booth and I would drink my sprite and my mom would get her tea or iced cold coke with a straw. My mom loved to dress up so she would be in her endless Macy's designer Jeans or an expensive skirt suit. 

My mother would order sashimi and she would always get me the shrimp tempura. 

Food then was better. The taste and quality were impeccable. The tempura had large tiger prawns, huge vegetables, good rice and excellent friendly service.

As a child I placed Tempura as my favorite food then macaroni and cheese and mcdonalds burgers would fall in after this place.

I remember after leaving this place, my mom and I would go to the Hello Kitty store and I'd get one toy or a bunch of stickers for being "good" and then we'd go to a cake shop called Marie Antoinette.
Think Andersen's bakery dessers but alot better quality than Andersens. My mom would buy me a cream puff, and a box of chocolate dream cakes, strawberry short cakes, fruit flans, and cheesecakes to take home for the family. I always had a pleasant time going to Japantown. Now as an adult, I still like Japantown, but realize now that it was alot better in quality as a child.
author: Charlene C.

description:
I know J-Town fairly well.
Hell, the place practically sustained me for 2 full years when I used to live nearby and eat here often... very, very often.

I've eaten most everything on the menu at Kushi Tsuru and think I've got a pretty good handle on the place.

My recommendations are to stick with the simple, homestyle dishes.  Go with the noodles or the curry, you won't lose.  While the food won't knock your socks off, it will go down pleasantly and fill that hollow void you call a stomach.  Prices are fair, and portions are decent.

Better yet, come for the lunch sets and get a load of food for an even better deal.
author: Gracie-C Y.

description: I've never had a bad experience at this restaurant and i've been coming here for years. The service has always been friendly, and I've always received my meals quickly, whether I was with two people or multiple people. My go-to meal here, and hands down my favorite, is the zaru soba. SO GOOD. And the dipping sauce is delicious as well. The gyoza are absolutely great as well, and you get quite a bit of food for the price. I went yesterday with my boyfriend during the Cherry Blossom festival, and despite the massive amount of people at the festival, and the fact that there were two parties ahead of us, the wait was short and the service was still quick. On a normal business day, I've never experienced a wait to be seated. I wouldn't let the, sadly, negative experiences that have been written about deter you from coming here. It's a great little restaurant with an intimate atmosphere and friendly, prompt service.
author: Angela M.

description:
-"Do you smell that?"
-"Yeah, you?"
-"Hell yeah, lets go"
Came here after roaming Japan town for a little R&R.   Maybe its that we had a late lunch, shopped for hours, or plainly had smelled something good, but we decided to try Kushi Tsuru.

The place is very small, luckily we went at 4 pm, so no lunch/dinner crowd.  I was glad they were still open as most Japanese restaurants close to prepare for dinner patrons.  

I got the Kastudon ($7.25) and my girlfriend ordered  a something-don (I will edit when I find out).  The Katsudon (fried egg and pork cutlet over rice) was very fresh tasting.  Grilled green and white onions complimented the pork and rice with more flavor. I fell in love at first bite and didn't stop until I had cleaned out the bowl. 

My first impression of price was that it was a little expensive, but upon finishing, I thought it was about right for what you got.  Service was very attentive but we were also 1 of the 2 patrons in there. Oh I forgot, we also got miso soup and this stale looking coleslaw that I didn't touch, anyone know what the coleslaw is for? I'm curious.

So maybe I was really hungry and that swayed my review a little...
Ah who cares, I'll come back for more!
author: Jason T.

description:
Attentive but not intrusive service. Good food. 

The sashimi melted in my mouth, so somebody knew what they were doing with a knife.  The tempura was delightfully non-greasy. The flavoring of the food was subtle and not overly salted ("bland" to other reviewers).  

I liked the ambiance of the place - old style Japantown of a few decades ago.  It's not a "scene", just straight ahead good Japanese food.  If you're looking for a good meal, this is the place.  If you're looking for a "dining experience" and like to send food back to the kitchen to impress your date, I have the same advice that cranky bartender at the Zab Zum Zum used to offer, "I think you'll find that there's a nice place in the next block that would be more to your liking."  

I like restaurants with "combo platters" (known in Japanese restaurants as bento) so I don't have to deal with wait persons bugging us with various courses.  This place has some great combo platters.  As with most Japanese restaurants, the wine is drinkable, but not much more. The clientele was well-behaved and there I didn't see any cell phonies or yuppie mommys and daddies in the place. There were mostly Japanese diners and some tourists, and not many locals.  That suits me just fine.  We were treated like guests in the old style Japanese way.  

I want to thank all of the reviewers who found this place to be bad or mediocre.  Keeps the snoots away from a restaurant I like.  I've been there several times and have never been disappointed.  Keep up the bad reviews. There's an ap for that: It's called I think you'll find that there's a nice place in the next block that would be more to your liking.
author: Dovetonsil W.

description:
The only place I ever go in J-town. Reason? Cheap, good, and nice staff.
I can go and wait for half an hour for my boyfriend, just sipping tea and reading my recently purchased Manga, and they don't bug me. In fact, they smile and ask if I want more tea while I wait :)

I almost always order the same thing, and the meal ends up being a little under 15 bucks, including tip (And I always tip well as they're so nice)

California roll and Chicken teriyaki Teishoku.
Comes with rice, miso and of course, picked veggies (I don't like em though)

Yes, it's incredibly Americanized, and the wait staff are Chinese. Over in Benihani, they're Mexican, so get over it.

It's tasty, cheap enough, and a nice environment. I love Kushi Tsuru
author: Adria W.

description:
Came here with my roommate, since we were both craving ramen. It was our first time here, and we made it before the end of the lunch special times, so we both got the #2 special: Ramen with 6pc CA roll.

Ramen was unremarkable. Not enough veggies and other ingredients to compliment the noodles. Both of us got soy sauce flavored broth, but it was so SALTY! CA roll tasted more bland than usual because of this.

Will not be back.
author: Sharlene C.

description:
Me and my  boss love this place for their tempura and noodles! Sometimes their soup is too hot so I also get some of their good pickles.
We come at least twice a month for lunch and take our vendors here for dinner. It's not like the better tempura stands in Japan, but, hey, we are in America and it beats Benihana!
author: Minnie-Mousse' M.

description: I'd give it 3.5 if that were an option. Solid sushi, reasonable prices, and good service. For dessert go to the market and get some lemon and grape Hi-Chews! Betcha didn't even KNOW there were lemon Hi-Chews did you? You're welcome..
author: Michael K.

description: This is an OK Sushi Place for Japan Center.  I came here with a few friends and we all ordered different variations of the combo lunch.  The food was subpar.  The service was very quick and we were pretty hungry so we were grateful for that.  What I want to know is how come the miso soup didn't have any tofu in it? What gives?  I've never had miso without tofu.  Shouldn't it be called something else?  Otherwise, I don't have any complaints about this place.
author: Amy J.

description: This used to be a great place to get kushi yaki, Japanese shish kebobs, but something happened. Not sure if there was an owner ship change or pressure to serve 'Amerika maki' like every other Japanese restaurant, but it has really gone down hill. I really wish Japanese restaurants could exist in the US like they do in Japan--focusing on one or two specialties and not having to cave to the demand for sushi all te time.
author: 和子

description:
HORRIBLE SERVICE!!! RUDE, RUDE, RUDE!!!

I had friends from NY visiting and decide to bring them to Japantown, they wanted Ramen and this was the closest place that popped up from my yelp search on my phone. We were quickly seated in the back and we checked on a few times by a nice young waitress to see whether we were ready to order. We had a party of eight, so it did take us awhile to get our orders ready-to-go. When we were finally ready to order, it was no longer the nice young waitress...but an older Chinese lady. We sat at a long table but there was enough room for her to stand at both ends, YET she stays at one end of the table where she first stood and shouted out "NEXT" without even making ANY eye contact after EACH of us kindly gave her our order. After the second "next" from her, I was already irritated outta my mind! SHE WAS PLAIN RUDE!!! My friends and I couldn't believed how rude she was!! When our orders came, she stood at the same spot that was at earlier and had us distribute each plate of our food to each other! WTF?!?! Where's our service?!?!? Was this a self-serve restaurant??!?! We were hesitant ask her for anything! She did not looked happy to deal with us and just seem unapproachable. We ate our food quickly because we wanted to leave this hell-hole ASAP. The behavior from this lady was really uncalled for, we have done nothing to deserve this kind of service. I don't understand how they can still be in business considering this kind of BAD service with mediocre food. Unfortunately, since we had more than six ppl, gratuity was already included, or else, that lady would not deserve even a single penny in tip from us!! 

There are many more restaurant in the Japantown mall than to risk your sanity of going here. Take my word for it, don't go here!!!
author: Winnie L.

description: Great service and convenient location. Had the tempura udon which was good, but not that special.
author: Emme K.

description:
Whenever I say J-Town, I always hear Mifune in the same breath. I don't even notice poor little Kushi Tsuru hanging out on the corner, inviting seats beckoning my rump to take a pause for the cause. I instead head for the beacon of noodles known as Mifune.

Well, Mifune, it looks like you've got some competition. In other words I may be visiting your homie Kushi a little more often. I rarely get cooked goods other than soup at Japanese restaurants, so I ventured here on a lark and decided that it's time to have a teri-something. The food didn't disappoint, and I'm certain that the food is of high quality. Husbandido loved his sukiyake; I adored my chicken teri. I never clean my plate like that. If I wasn't a refined individual like the queen I am, I would have licked my plate. You think I'm joking.

Props for the service, which unlike Mifune, was not brisk and bustling all in your grill. You rarely notice that someone's swept a bowl off your table, or that your tea was refilled. I like it like that, don't you? Good value for what you pay.
author: Charlene L.

description:
When I was in high school, this place was a fun place to come on a Friday for lunch. They had a bento box that was a pretty good deal, and if you were sat in the front room it was pretty fun.

Well, we went here Saturday before heading over to see The Prestige at the *Sundance* theater and the memory was better than the experience. The sushi and teriyaki dishes were similar to mall food, and we were sat in the blah back section. The only good point was the friendly service. I don't think I will come back again. It's best to let the memory lie.
author: Dixon T.

description: The Ramen lunch special ain't all that great. For $8 you do get a BIG bowl of Ramen, and once the waiter sets it right in front of your face you couldn't be any happier. "Wow $8 for all this??"  Buuut once you actually taste the soup and noodles, it's quite disappointing. I would say Top Ramen actually has more flavor. However, the mackerel was very good! Really succulent and only $9 for that, miso, salad and rice. So I suggest when you come here, don't get the ramen and order a combo instead!
author: Alexa M.

description:
Like many before me, I am here to extol the deliciousness of the dish San Francisco Fire.  Spicy tuna that is actually quite spicy (yes!), quick tempura dip and fry on the outside (hell yes!), on a bed of greens and seaweed salad.  Two things I would change about it: 1) less lettuce, more seaweed and 2) put the dressing on the salad not just around the rim of the plate...it made it more difficult to shovel it into my pie hole.

Ambiance isn't good.  Not bad either though...just blah.

I would go back for the SF Fire dish repeatedly,  and probably would never even try anything else on the menu.  No need, I already know what I want.
author: Beth G.

description: The best shoyu Ramen hands down. Better than Tanpopo. The service was great and fast. I will come back again.
author: Bryan H.

description:
Tempura Soba, Tempura Udon, Bento Box (w/ tempura and nigiri)-- in general the portions were small

I'd recommend getting the combination where you can pick two main entrees. 

Con: waitress poured tea in my cup, and then stared at my cup for a little while, then removed my cup and came back with another teacup. I'm assuming she saw some unfriendly critter swimming in my teacup.
author: Jenny K.

description:
I know someone who raves about this place so I've gone twice now to give it a good chance. This person has no real experience with real sushi so I should have known better. Most of the food in Japantown is mediocre and this is no different. 

The decor and ambiance is sweet but in no way makes up for the lack of flavor and freshness.
author: Erin D.

description: I went during the evening and Kushi was the only place in J-town that didn't have a wait and at the same time affordable. Service was pretty quick. I was looking through the menu and saw the combination section. Two seleections for ~$11.00. I ordered a Chicken "Kara-age" (I think that's what it's called) and some California Rolls. It also came with Miso soup and rice. The soup was good. The rice was sticky just the way I like it. The chicken and California were alright too. I'm just satisfied that it filled me up. And they actually gave my change back!
author: Gerard Y.

description: One of my favorite restaurants in the Restaurant Mall of JTown. Great bento boxes! Very fresh and very tasty. Decent prices. I always leave with a satisfied appetite and wallet:)
author: Tracy N.

description: The portions are small for the amount that you pay...the shrimp and veggie tempera appetizer has 2 shrimps and 1 broccoli for 6 bucks...sigh the sushi had a sloppy presentation for the price I rather go to benihanna next door
author: W Y.

description: This place is awesome.  Pair great service with proven classics and bold concepts, and add some great real Japanese beer, and you have a fun meal!  We had rolls with mango and tuna and those were amazing - loved the California rolls and the maki too.
author: James V.

description:
This was the place we passed up in favor of the "Keanu Reeves ate here" restaurant. Turns out we actually did the right thing.

One star for the service, and because Yelp doesn't seem to allow half-stars. Our waitress was fine, and didn't seem put out that we sent her away 2 or 3 times before finally making up our minds.

Why did it take so long? Because the selection was awful, and the prices steep (8 bucks for a 6-piece unagi and avocado roll?). We nearly left, and should have. Instead we soldiered on. My girlfriend got udon, I got some of the overpriced sushi.

That rock 'n' roll wasn't awful -- a little more avocado than you'd normally get in a roll like that, for one thing -- but the rice they added to this one so that they could overcharge for it was evidently skimped from the sake nigiri, a thin sad slice of salmon on a threadbare blanket of rice. For $12 I could have stuffed myself in any other sushi place I've ever been to, but here it was barely an appetizer. I'd easily pay $12 for one quality roll, but these weren't any such thing.

My girlfriend's experience was the clincher here, though. Noodles with obvious just-out-of-a-package creases, and something that didn't seem to be chicken she had to spit out into a napkin. I've never seen her do that before.

NEVER coming back. There are several totally decent places in Japantown and sometimes branching out is a mistake.
author: Drew S.

description:
This is my favorite Japanese restaurant in Japan Town. I've eaten at most of the restaurants there and always decide that this one is the best. Since this place isn't the most popular in J.T (like Mifune), it's usually pretty easy to get seated quickly.

The waitresses are always very nice and it's very fast. It's not a fantastic restaurant, but one of my regular haunts.
author: Yvette K.

description:
Came here with the family and had a really nice experience. We were all starving and we were seating in 10 min, in the back booth. It was spacious and it was bustling with people having a good time. 

We tried everything! and it was all delicious! 

- Shabu Shabu: thin sliced beef & vegetables cooked in broth. served with special dipping sauce 
- Seafood Teppan
- Combination box: Chicken teriyaki & vegetable tempura
- Pink Lady roll - super yummy! 

We also got a variety of nigiris and the fish was super fresh. 

Their plum wine is really yummy too! Definitely coming back here again.
author: Gladys C.

description:
This place is great. Customer service is excellent, as well as the food.

I love the Udon here and my friends love the Bento Boxes. Always a lot of delicious food for not that much money.

Try anything, it's going to be great and filling.
author: Rec T.

description: I've been going there since they opened in 1978 and it's still run by the same family, although the son of the original owner did not seem to put much energy into the business. The daughter is running it now and it appears to be undergoing a gradual re-inventing. The menu is traditional and diverse. Great selections for everyone. The nouveau sushi creations are very filling and fun. Traditional dishes are just what you would expect from a family establishment: satisfying an flavorful. A great place to go with people have have diverse taste and preferences: something good for everyone!
author: Joe B.

description: Wife and I ate here after a spa visit. Needless to say we were both in post massage famished mode. I ordered the Ten Don and my wife had an assorted bento. Both were very good! The service was quick and friendly but not overly annoying. Would definitely come back!
author: Steven E.

description:
Well these places in the Japantown Mall... hmm they are hit or miss and tend to cater a bit to tourists, it seems. but that being said, if you avoid Benihana at all costs, you won't do that bad.

The staff was nice here. Service was very fast. Food was good. Sushi is not remarkable at all, but they have a good yet simple variety.

Hmm, it's OK! I'd visit again :-)
author: Aaron W.

description:
The most un-Japanese restaurant in the Kintetsu Mall.  In fact, it's the most Chinese-American restaurant in Japantown.  Chinese by the waitstaff (and cooks?!) and by the way even the tsukemono tasted Chinese.

Horrific "Kaiseiki Bento."  Explaining it would be like living it all over.  Trust me.

Will never go here again.  For real Japanese food, I should know better than to go to the tourist mall, but we were in the neighborhood.

Thankfully, the bill was about $35.  Not cheap, but at least not in the $50-$60 range.  I would have cried.
author: Penny P.

description:
I don't even remember what I got here, it was a few months ago.  

But my friend ordered this Japanese alcohol drink in a bottle.  It was in a pink bottle and kind of looked like pepto bismol.  Anyway, he had ordered the wrong size I get, and got a big one that cost 8 dollars, even though he really wanted the 3 dollar smaller size.  
After he drank the whole thing he realized what happened and tried to explain it to the server.  They ended up splitting the difference and charged him $5, since he drank the whole thing.
So far stars for at least compromising.
author: Levi B.

description:
Not bad. I had the soba special for lunch. It was a lot of food. BFF had a combo lunch thingy and a roll. Everything was pretty good and out total bill was around $35. That's on the pricier side for me, but I got to have lunch with my BFF in Japantown.

Service was really good. They were really helpful and attentive.
author: Wendy B.

description: This was the second I visit this place in over five years. The service is pretty friendly. I am not a big fan of Japanese food, so I tried a variety of stuff. I had an eel sushi which was really good and fresh, too bad the portions are small, and the prices a bit high. I had the bentobox dinner which consist of eel fish, tofu, salad and some fried vegetables. It was pretty good, and the prices for bentoboxes are reasonable. My husband had the some kind of seafood platter which he said was pretty good, the only thing was he wishes the portions were larger...lol. Overall experience was great...the people are nice, and we love the miso soup...so yummy and the green tea is free.
author: Jenny W.

description: We eat here just about every time we come to J-Town. They have a great variety on their menu. Depending on what side of the restaurant you sit on you can get a great booth with a little bit of privacy or a sucky booth or table where you are almost on top of your neighbors. Service is polite but usually overworked so you will need to ask them when you want more water or tea but you get your food in a timely manner and they won't rush you out the door. The portions are great so you get what you pay for. Favorites include Dragon Roll and tori kaaraage. Miso soup is not salted to death, it has a wonderful flavor instead.
