author: Brett L.

description: The food probably rates at a high three. I enjoyed my dish but it wasn't anything the stood out compared to other Japanese restaurants that I have been to but the service was great which is why I gave it four stars. The staff was very friendly and always checked in on us. I enjoyed my visit here.
author: Michael G.

description:
I came here for lunch with a friend and geez. We thought it would be a bit touristzy and like Mifune. As it turned out, we were greeted at the door, seated and served hot tea in an instant. Lady poured us hot tea when the tea came. A plus in my book. When we ordered, the miso and pickled vegetables tasted delicious. I ordered the Chirashi sushi and the presentation was really nice! it seemed really pretty but since I was craving sashimi all week, I dug right in. Yummy!

For $12.95, I got more than what I paid for! =]
author: Jason C. J.

description:
This place will do if I had to pick along that side of the hallway in Japantown.

Miso soup was better than I expected, with more flavor. The pickle-course is still an American phenomenon I can't get used to. And the little pile of salty cabbage was not worth the spotlight on its own. It should be a side with rice, don't treat it like a salad.

Mango Paradise, the 8-piece specialty roll was okay, but the critical mango was under ripe. In fact, some of us thought it was a cuke. I've had decent rolls there in the past; the fish and tobiko somewhat made up for it but I'll try to order safer rolls next time.

Kara-age, my yardstick for Japanese mom & pop shops, and this place failed miserably. The chicken pieces were the size of croutons and were about that dry and crunchy. NOT GOOD, folks.

Tempura was better, but could have been less greasy - however, I don't set too high a standard at this level. A good variety of veggies and the shrimp was passable. It was also served hot, so that's a plus for not having sat around.

My non-Asian friends were happy with the meal and I think it passed as Japanese to me by the skin of its teeth, but only because they're next to Mifune and Osaka-ya, where I've had such abhorrent dining memories,  I will never return to either.
author: Bibi B.

description: Me and friends eat here once in a while. The service is good, the food is good, the price is within our budget our my waiter is calm and respectful to all of his customers who sit in his area, but all of his other staff members including the owner has attitude problems. A staff member was cleaning a table and broke a couple of plates, another staff was standing there and NOT helping. The owner toss us the check and didn't bother to look at us. Within 10 seconds, he grabbed the check before I can put my credit card on the tray. He did the same by tossing the check when I'm ready to sign the check. With bad attitudes and the owner tossing the check to us DESERVES NO TIP. Just we're about to leave the owner then gave us a smile and said, "hope you come back next time". We are NOT going back there
author: Samuel Y.

description: This dining experience was pretty awesome. Our server was super nice and made sure we were happy with everything. I got a combination meal of tonkatsu and tempura. It came with miso soup and rice. While I never finish the rice, I wish they gave me a spoon with my miso soup. The tonkatsu and tempura were great. Towards the end of my meal she asked if we wanted dessert and I asked if they made fried ice cream. From her response, it didn't seem like they did, but she said she would see what she could do. She ended up bringing a plate out with three difference fried ice creams. One green tea, one strawberry, one vanilla. They were awesome.
author: M C.

description:
This restaurant has become my unit of measurement for meals in Japantown. Quick, attentive, delicious, and relatively cheap.
Granted there is nothing special about the ambiance here, but try their spicy tuna roll over the seaweed salad with their house dressing and TELL ME you wouldn't eat here as much as you can. I dare you!
The staff is very nice, very astute, and there's always new specials to try.
author: E.Mo. ..

description:
My other half and I decided to try Japantown for the first time since we moved to San Francisco over a year ago.  We had some recommendations, particularly for Mifune, but when I saw the focus was on noodles and I wanted something a little less "carby", we happened upon Kushi Tsuru.

Basic decor, very friendly service.  The lunch started well enough, with the miso soup having a nice fermented tang to it, and the edamame fresh and hot and salty.  But it went a little downhill for there.  My other half's sushi (rainbow rolls, eel rolls and spicy tuna rolls) weren't very good.  Not bad or expired, just something a little off.  My sukiyaki bowl was ok, but rather bland.  And they didn't use the best cuts of beef.

So, service was 4 stars, decor 2, appetizers 4, main course 2, price 3 (it's certainly reasonably priced).
author: Jacques P.

description:
Me and my boyfriend wanted some good Japanese food. So where do you go? JAPAN TOWN of course! We chose Kushi Tsuru because of the cute fake model food in the display window. Mainly because of the delicious sauce filled clams that we were craving. 

Unfortunately, the plastic food from the display window looked and probably tasted better than the food we were served. 
The clams ($9) were boiled in tap water and has no sauce in site (10 pieces). 

The chicken katsu was especially bland and smaller than I ever seen (6 MINI pieces).

The curry was directly from the on-sale-already expired-one minute mix curry powder from safeway select. It didn't only look OLD, but tasted like shoe with huge halves of potatoes because the chef was too lazy to chop them. 

Our server was angry with us, the world and her job apparently. She treated us like we owed her family money for YEARSSSS! She was not only rude to us, but she also seemed to HATE the couple next to us. (Possibly owed her family lots of money as well). She forced them to accept the food that she had mis-ordered for them and insisted that the price was the same anyway, so who cares?! The customer unwillingly gave in, only to receive a look of frustration from the server and to eat the food that they didn't order! (Silly customers trying to eat the food that they wanted, and not the food that she ordered for them). 

F.Y.I~ I especially signed up for a Yelp account to write a review to SAVE your money, happiness and stomach from displeasure and despair!
author: Apple W.

description:
This place is not good at all.  We ordered softshell crabs and they weren't even crispy.  They were very oily and soggy.   Either they didn't fry at the right temperature or they pulled them out too early.... not very sure but obviously they didn't do it right.

Edamame was very soggy also.  Other orders were not good either.  We went here when my family was in town but they weren't impressed either.  Avoid this place if you can.
author: toddy h.

description: Food alone earns this place 3 stars.  The agedama tofu and sukiyaki were both delicious and in generous portions, a perfect fit after a busy day of shopping.  The ambience (which earns the additional star) was quite intriguing.  Small but not cramped, dining in the mini space while people watching, complete with all the faux-foods models outside, reallly plays on the fantasy of being in a foreign land.  This is complemented by all the light chattering by other patrons around us in Japanese.  I last visited Japan as a child 25 years ago, and thist setting conjured up something deep.  I will return not just for the food, but for nostalgic reasons.  Check it out for yourself.
author: Peter C.

description: We decided to try a different restaurant in Japantown from our usual, and I picked Kushi Tsuru because they have a vegetarian bento box. (I don't eat fish.)  The  vegetarian bento had an attractive presentation and came with soba noodles, tofu, and cucumber rolls -- all very good. We also enjoyed chicken skewers as an appetizer. The service was fast. I would definitely come back to try other things on the menu.
author: Michael B.

description:
i had intended to end up at another spot that yelp had rated highly in this mall, but we ended up arriving too late (2 pm) and the other place was closed. lucky for us, because the food here was very good and inexpensive.

the atmosphere wasn't very exciting. the plates were cute, but it was a little dark. i was next to the open window, and some britney spears music was loudly coming in from some other store nearby. another day i walked by and there was no music.

the chicken/egg donburi (oyako don) was satisfying, the hamachi kama was delicious and tender . it was 7 or 8$.
author: Anna S.

description:
I recently had a late lunch at Kushi Tsuru and was extremely disappointed.  This is a restaurant in Japantown and one would expect that the food would be edible.

The man who was helping us spilled the hot tea all over the table and us.  The rice was crunchy.  The rest of the meal was terrible.

If you are starving and all the other restaurants in Japantown ran out of food and caught on fire, consider eating at Kushi Tsuru.
author: Kyle I.

description: This is one of my favorite spots to eat at in Japantown. Service may be spotty because of the few amount of waiters/waitresses when its kinda busy, but when its slow, their service is on point. Food may be mediocre & may taste like every other Japanese restaurant, but something about this place keeps on making me come back. I have tried the other restaurants in the centre, but I guess they just don't cut it for me compared to Kushi Tsuru.
author: BrendaJoy G.

description: Ramen was good, but included ONE slice of pork, and maybe like 5 bean sprouts, and really not much of anything except for noodles.
author: Christopher L.

description:
i can be very stubborn. ive tried to get over this. 

it seems like i can put it aside for awhile, but it just comes right back. 

after the miserable fail that was soba at mifune, days later, i was still craving some soba, ummm decent, edible soba.

ive never noticed this place. to be honest, when im walking through this hallway, its usually to get to or from makis and sophies.

i parked. 

i got in the elevator. 

i had the idea to eat mifune again just to be completely fair about that shitty review..... kushi tsuru caught my eye.

hey japanese staff.... a good sign....

ordered tempura with soba.....

oooo the noodles look different...... WTF!!!!!!!!!! mushy and grainy. i literally wanted to spit it out, but i was just waving to the cute little kid across from me. it would be in poor taste to spit out my food in front of a kid....

the soba dipping sauce was good, but i mean.... how hard is it to pour it from a bottle right? but again.... dried up scallion and no grated radish?

the tempura was decent enough.... well actually, the batter was a bit heavy, thick. not light and fluffy. 

the search for decent, edible soba continues..

WTH MAN you boil some water. add in dried soba noodles. cook for a few mintues.... rinse in icy water. chop up scallions. grate radish. add some water to powder wasabi.... how hard can this be?
author: Euge L.

description:
While the curry is just a notch below Osakaya, unlike that place I didn't walk outta here still hungry. 

I loved the cozy interior and ambiance the whole place had, I always tend to just eat and then leave as soon as possible but over here I actually felt like staying and relaxing lol. 

Also outta the three restaurants that sit side by side next to each other (Osakaya,Mifune,Kushi Tsuru) this one probably has the best service..both attentive and nice. And it's probably not even worth mentioning but outta the three this place also has the best miso soup lol. 

One star knocked off because they were just a bit skimpy on the beef in my curry, but plenty of hearty chunks of carrots and potatoes. I'll definately be coming back to try the other stuff.
author: Mike A.

description:
After a rough night of basketball, I was hungry for something light.  I suggested to T that we try Suzu in Japantown, so we headed out that way.  Upon arriving, we saw that it was closed Tuesdays.  It was already about 9p, so we decided to see what was still open.  We walked upstairs and came upon Kushi Tsuru.  In the past, I've been suckered into going to Mifune next door and I know a lot of tourists like to frequent this 'strip'.  But looking at the menu, it didn't seem bad.  Besides, my stomach began to growl...or was that T's?

We went in and were quickly seated.  T opted for the Chicken Udon, and I decided, since we were gonna share the soup, on a dinner combo of chicken karaage and salmon sashimi.   A nice large Sapporo also quenched our thirst.  The food came out quickly.  While I'm used to seeing a dinner combo in a bento box, no box came with this meal, which was fine with me.  It's usually hard to eat from the box, so I preferred the bowl of rice and separate plates.  The sashimi was good, not the best, but satisfying, as was the karaage. T's bowl of udon was huge.  The udon was tender and chewey, but not overcooked.  And the broth was very good.  I think I should've stuck to my original plan and ordered the udon, but I suppose I can do that the next time.  Prices were very reasonable, being that it's in the Mall.  And the staff were also very friendly and quick.  Will definitely go back if I need an udon fix or a quick meal.
author: JeFF T.

description: The restaurants in Japantown are expensive. Kushi Tsuru is one of the cheaper restaurants.  For $13.00, you get a bento combo.  I ordered the chicken katsu for $11.  My meal tasted good.  Nothing gave me the wow, you must eat here.  The salad tasted terrible.  The dressing was sour such that it tasted spoiled.  The bento combo my friend ordered included two items, rice, soup, and salad.  I visited other restaurants that give something extra in bento boxes.  In short, the bento combos are standard.  Sodas are served in cans.
author: Raymond M.

description:
dont come here for sushi, but everything else sure why not~

typical place with bento boxes and ramen and etc.

i cant really say much more about it, I dont eat here often but I know Ive never had a bad experience so that must be a good thing.
author: phillip w.

description: So originally I was at lunch with a friend down the street when there was a loud bang and smoke pouring from the space next door which lead to the SF FD coming down and the two of us being left to find a new spot for lunch. Well after walking through the Japan Center we decided upon Kushi Tsuru. We were seated and brought a pot of hot green tea. Our orders were taken and arrived shortly after. The food was good the service was good too. Nothing super special  but definitely solid for what its worth.
author: Chris W.

description: After trying the Ozeki Hana Awaka sparkling sake here, we decided to pick up a few bottles from the market because we enjoyed it so much. Unfortunately, we had no luck locating it anywhere. But somehow, I ended up buying a couple $10 Japanese magazines even though I can't read them. Drinking Ozeki Hana Awaka will sure give you determination and drive.
author: Connie C.

description: could be a bit cleaner, but for normal priced Japanese food full of flavor and prompt service, we often bypass the looks.  It's an old building too, so I understand.  This is the only place we eat in Japan town.  It's a pretty standard menu, but they seem do do everything well.
author: Kimbra O.

description: Relatively slow service. The beef teriyaki I had was probably 60% fat. I took a picture of it and uploaded it here. The salmon teriyaki my friend came in a very small portion, didn't taste fresh at all and a bit hard to chew. The floor is a bit dirty too.
author: Alvin B.

description:
i think there's a threshold for snootiness in regards to japanese food--a lot of sushi snobs out there, and i'd love to say i'm one of them, but then i find myself liking places most people seem displeased about. yes, i'm one of those who lived in japan for a while, and that has colored my impression of japanese food. 

personally, i hate california rolls, and love finding items on menus that are not average fare. case in point, i have not found any place that serves kushi-age in america, besides kushi tsuru. i thought it was pretty darn well made, and tasted pretty decent. i think the trick is finding what dish a japanese restaurant does well, and going there for that reason. what makes this difficult is that nearly every japanese restaurant in jtown serves the same standard fare. i don't think i'd come here strictly for sushi (which was decent, but not awesome). the name of the restaurant is kushi tsuru. they deal with stuff on sticks. i would stick to cooked foods here, specifically the kushi-age combinations. 

i love traditional japanese bento boxes (the ones that have a plum in the rice, with little stewed vegetables and little sides in the corners). i like the variety of side dishes that come. i can't say this place blows and think i'm all hot stuff, because i genuinely liked it. not every place will have mind-blowing sushi, but this place is made of sturdy stuff. i really enjoy that they give you hot green tea when you sit down. the servers were really nice, and thats great by me for a nice place to eat. i recommend.
author: Jade L.

description:
my favorite family style restaurant in Japantown

this is where I come after the Kabuki Hot Springs or before or after a movie from the Kabuki Theater (soon to repoen as a Sundance theater - yay!!). I will also just stop here if I'm on my way home on the 38 Geary. (Get out at the Webster stop and head up the Japantown staircase. It's so easy and convenient.) 

This place is so reliable. Everything is fresh, fairly cheap and what I consider to be good Japanese family style food. My daughter and her friends always love to eat with me here, too. 

I recommend the tataki salad ~ a staple for me ~ a nice crunchy green salad with lots of seared tuna ~ a delicious and light meal which I usually fill out by adding a couple of Kushi (fried items with batter on a bamboo skewer & dipping sauce) the garlic, potato, tuna and salmon ones are particulary good. In fact I like the tuna ones the best, but I don't even know if they're still on the menu. They changed this menu somewhat recently -- I've been coming for years, so I go ahead and order the tuna anyway. The kushi is what the restaurant is named for so you have to try at least 1 or 2.

Their sushi is not a highlight, but I appreciate that they almost always have fresh uni. This makes a nice side to my meal, too. My daugher and her friends always order one of the Udon specials--seaweed, tempura, or tofu. 

The grilled eggplant with sweet miso sauce is also nice (but sweet!) Nice to pair it with something more savory.

fast, reliable, centrally located, and very dependable for a good homey meal...follow up with a creme brulee at the Anderson Bakery right across the hall ~ absolutely perfect creme brulee.

update: menu's overhauled--no tataki salad--but seared albacore is on the sashimi menu. no individual kushi (this is very sad!) but you can still get a kushiage dinner (lots of kushi). their fish and sushi are so very fresh though.
author: Liza B.

description: This is inside the Kintetsu building in Nihonmachi (Japan Town) in restaurant row, and like Japan, they have the pastic food in the window to show what they have. You expect so-so food and high prices, being in the mall and all, but actually the food is pretty good and the prices are reasonable for the city. I had one "shoka-do" of several Bento box choices ($10 - $15), which came with miso soup, tsukemono (pickled veggies),  tempura (2 shrimp 4 veggies) grilled salmon (small piece), kushi, and 7 pieces of sashimi, all for $15!. Combination chicken teriyaki and tempura was $11.50 with rice, soup and tsukemono. Hot green tea is no charge. The atmosphere is casual, the help is a mixture of Korean and other asians. If it is crowded at Mifune, this isn't a bad alternative, and you might just like to go there first.
author: Wanugee N.

description: Great food on our trip to japan town! The Miso soup was to die for! very yummy! I enjoyed the sashimi and my husband loved the teriyaki chicken! Great service too! will definitely be going back on our next trip!
author: karyn m.

description: Very happy they didn't sink the ebi tempura into the udon and make it all soggy!!! 3 stars for that alone! The waitstaff were welcoming and hey, udon was okay, not overcooked or under cooked. Surprised
author: miriam b.

description:
kind of like a one night stand - not really memorable.

they don't validate - not that parking in j-town is expensive...

sometimes you get what you pay for.  inexpensive grub  = mediocre food.  i had the ramen with a tasty fried crab thinghie.  then again, anything deep fried is good.  the beef donburi was filling but not satisfying.

so a cheap date but i'll throw away the number if i were you.
author: Anh V.

description: Okay get this.... this place is owned and run by actual Japanes people!  They speak Japanese and actually know what I mean when I ask for "Shichimi or Nanami tongarashii"!!  I've had a few different dishesh here, sukiyaki is yummy and not overly laden with too much sugar or "shoppai" too salty.  Their Zaru soba (cold and hot) is pretty tasty without over cooked noodles or too watery "Tsuyu" (the sauce to dip your noodles in).  The only reason I'm dinging them for the one star was the service- a bit slow esp. on Fri or Sat nights.  If you like chicken teriyaki you get a nice sized portion or bang for your buck here!  A definite frequent haunt for me!
author: Alicia W.

description: This restaurant is located within Japantown and one of the ones with mediocre price for a Japanese restaurant. I ordered the katsu rice bowl and the portion was pretty large. I was suprised that I finished it and boy was i bloated. they also served miso soup like any other japanese restaurant would. Coming from a person who doesnt have the taste buds nor appreciate miso soup, it was quite taste and i was pleased with that. the only thing that ticked me off was that the waitress looked like she was rushing us out.
author: J. W.

description: We came here for dinner because it was pretty cheap (compared to the other restaurants in japantown) and we were on a budget. We both got combos and they were around $11 I think? It was okay food, but the teriyaki chicken tasted a bit burnt. The portions were smaller than I'm used to, but it was the right amount because we could finish it all and we weren't still hungry afterwards. Service was okay too. I'm not sure if I'll come back.
author: Christine C.

description: Kushi has good prices, good service, and good food.  It's not the best I've had, but I always find myself going to this restaurant because of what I've mentioned above.
author: Daniel T.

description: When Mifune is too busy this is my second best restaurant. Excellent sukiyaki (my mom loves it and she's 100% japanese), and I pig out on the okinomiyaki (japanese pancake) till i'm a round bouncy ball. Another inexpensive good place to chow down on some sushi too.
author: Rachel R.

description:
Love, Love, Love this place. I have been going to Kushi for as long as I can remember. It is probably my favorite Japanese restaurant in the city. The place itself needs to be freshened up quite a bit. In the last 20 years the only two things that have changed are that they now give you a whole can when you order a coke and the menus themselves. 

The food is why you come come here. It is fresh and the prices are pretty fair. The service is ok. Avoid the bathroom, its pretty disgusting. Take some Purell Hand sanitizer, that will do. Everybody, I have ever taken to Kushi enters with that look of yuck, but they leave very grateful for discovering this gem in the rough. 

If you appreciate good authentic fresh Japanese food, then definitely give Kushi a try. If you can stomach Costco prepared sushi with the imitation crab meat, well than God bless you.
author: Steve G.

description: So my gf and I came here wanting some udon soup. So I ordered the tempura udon and the broth was good, neither salty or bland. I like the way they put my shrimp tempura on the side instead of letting it get soggy in my soup while serving me.  The atmosphere was calming but it was really warm in there and our table was wobbly.  As everyone else stated the sushi wasn't so fresh and the tables were to cramped together. Service wise I don't really have anything to complain about.
author: Jeremiah B.

description: I haven't eaten at many Japanese restaurants, but I enjoyed Kushitsuru. I had the cd plater which had teriyaki chicken, sushi and fried fish. The sushi was very fresh and flavorful, teriyaki was good although a little fatty and the fried fish was good but the sauce tasted a little too much like generic tarter sauce. The service was friendly and efficient. Ambiance was nice, but not spectacular and the ave price was in the $10-15 range. On the whole, I enjoyed the meal and it is a good option when in J-town, but I probably wouldn't go out of my way to eat there.
author: Russ C.

description:
Tonight, i came here for a late lunch with my coworker.  I usually walked passed by this restaurant many times, and their display is always so impressive and cute. I finally had a chance to try this place out.  The waitress was very accommodating and attentive.  From other reviews, they mentioned the waitress was Chinese, but today, the ones that was working spoke Japanese.  Anyhow, I ordered the sushi combo which comes with miso soup. My coworker is usually into anything that's in a soup form.. etc, ramen noodles.. so he had the Yosenabe, which was assorted seafood & vegetable cooked in broth with rice and miso soup too.  
I enjoyed my sushi/Sashimi a lot.  The texture of the fish was fresh that it's does melt in my mouth.  
Only thing i didn't really like was the fish and chip. The batter was too thick and hard.  And the fries was kind of over-fry.  They have a variety of rolls also.  Next time, i shall stick with the sushi and will want to try out the other noodles and the donburi instead.  Otherwise, nice and small cozy restaurant enviroment for their customer to enjoy their food.
author: Selina L.

description: Went here for lunch with some coworkers. Miso was salty and nothing to write home about. Donburi was flavorless, sashimi was meh at best, and the waitress forgot parts of our order. Two stars because nobody got sick. Not recommended.
author: Mark W.

description: I like Kushi Tsuru a lot.  That said, I usually order one of the giant, super americanized rolls (love the pink lady) and some sake.  My dad loved their chicken katsu, but he had never had chicken katsu before.  The rest of the food is standard J-town mall fare.  I much prefer it to Mifune, though.  The staff are much friendlier and most of the food I've had at mifune has been gross.
author: Stormageddon S.

description: I went to Japantown and was mesmerized by the look of the place so I went in to check it out. The menu doesn't have dishes that stick out, but I would guess that sushi is not their specialty. I had the salmon teriyaki with a salad and udon soup. The salad was good, the udon soup was amazing, and the salmon was good. Damn that udon soup was amazing though. The waitress was robot-like. She pretty much came, took our orders, filled our drinks, and smiled. She didn't really talk much. Me and my friend went at about noon so it was not too busy, so I would suggest going at that time. The prices were cheaper than what I've had at Japanese restaurants here in Denver, so I was happy. Try it out.
author: Clara M.

description: Good restaurant for good, authentic Japanese food, for reasonable price.  I have lived and work in Japan, so I know what is authentic Japanese food.  It is not a fancy place.  But you'll often find the local Japanese eating there, so that's assurance you're getting the real deal.  A general problem I find with many of the reviewers on Yelp is many are pretty clueless what is authentic ethnic food, be it Japanese, Chinese, French, etc.  You can't blame them since they have probably never had sufficient life experience or the opportunity to eat the authentic food, so they just don't know.
author: Ken V.

description: Typical Japanese Food menu. Sabu Sabu was served in a large bowl with enough beef and napa the noodles were stuck together and wouldn't come apart.  Guess that was the way they supposed to be.  Miso soup was pretty good.  Service was fine.  Teriyaki beef was better than most places.  I'd go back again.
author: patrick n.

description: They make really good Veggie Tempura! The best I've had so far. The Edamame wasn't bad either. And I don't even like Japanese food. Be prepared to wait for a table on most nights. The menu is pretty limited and won't blow you away.
author: Tushar V.

description: We ordered karaage (deep fried chicken) and we got something that resembled rabbit poops.
author: Seaweed F.

description: The display on the outside really lured me in to try this place . The shabu shabu was a rip off !! It was just a few pieces of meat and a few pieces of tofu . The meat was decent . The tofu was nice and firm . I didn't like the fact that almost the whole bowl was filled with lettuce . I rather just go shabu shabu for the price they charged for it . They had two dipping sauces .. ponzu and some other sauce . Ponzu is of course good but the other dipping sauce lacked flavor !! I ordered a sushi roll .. I forgot what it was called .. I believe it started with the letter K . Anywho , it wasn't superb but decent . Same goes with the spicy tuna . It wasn't really spicy and I've had fresher spicy tuna rolls . Overall , interesting and decent  place to dine for people who like to switch it up once in a while but overpriced . Don't let the display fool ya !!
author: Eileen L.

description: This restaurant is pretty mediocre.  Un-exciting menu and standard Americanized fare.  For $11.50 I got a "combo" dinner that consisted of a thin slice of salmon teriyaki, a 6-piece California roll, a bunch of rice, and a little bit of miso soup that doesn't taste that great.  And I have to oder some nigiri in addition to the combo, or else I will still be hungry.
author: Kandi K.

description: This place sucks!!!  Not only is this place expensive, but the food is bad.  The restaurant that is a store next to this one is better.  The service is ok and the food did not look so great.  I order a ramen and udon; the soup did not taste good.
author: HappyFeet K.

description: Super friendly folks here -- I give the service alone 5 stars.  Limited veggie options, but decent food overall.  I'd go back.
author: Andi T.

description: Mediocre, but not a wide variety selection of sushi. Have had better. The restaurant is small, but still enough room to eat. We got - a smoked salmon and California roll combo, and a vegetable udon soup. Overall, prices were fair and would come back in the FAR future.
author: Lisa C.

description: We were in the neighborhood and hungry and we looked thru the Japantown windows at the their faux food and we ended up choosing this place.  The service was friendly but the kitchen was kind of slow.  I got the chirashi delux and my food came out fast but my hubby got the chicken teridon and it did not come out til way after i was already done and ready to leave. lol. The sashimi was very fresh and the price wasn't bad.  My chirashi was only 10.95 and it's usually about 16-20 dollars elsewhere.
author: Kymberli C.

description: considering the restaurants in the same mall surrounding kushi tsuru sell similar fare, this restaurant is seriously not interested in the competition. Kushi Tsuru knows that it'll have customers regardless, because the other better restaurants fill up and spill into this one. It's over priced and the service is pretty horrendous - or maybe it was just our waitress- but she was hostile and forgot to take my order. When I said, "Miss, you forgot to take me order." she glared at me and started to rattle off the orders she did take. She read five items. There were six of us. I'd seriously never go back. GO TO MIFUNE, right next door!
author: Betty H.

description:
adore the sukiyaki. love the chirashi gozen. crazy about the otoko-yama.... i been eating in kushi tsuru for the longest i can remember. the staff is super friendly... they always ask whether i want to refill my miso or pickle, which i usually say " yess pleasee "
and they validated too :)
author: sherly A.

description: Decent food.. I ordered the cold soba noodles. They were kind of bland, but at least they came with green onions to jazz things up a bit. Would probably not go here again when in Japantown (I prefer Mifune, right next door).
author: O K.

description: This is my favorite restaurant in Japantown.  They offer a decent variety of food and the atmosphere is relaxing/low-key.  It's not really a sushi place, so go for a bento box.  Good place to eat before a show at the Fillmore.
author: Leah M.

description: my boyfriend and I ,along with another couple(all of us from outta town) came here to grab some sushi since all the other places were crowded. Once we were seated it took 20 mins for someone to even come over and recognize our table. The waitress just kept passing by us ,not even looking our way. After forever they finally took our order, she got my order of rolls wrong,but I just ignored it and ate them, I didn't want to argue. I figured it wouldn't help. The food was ok,nothing special. After we were done ,we asked for the bill. I was so use to seeing the tip added on the bill at every other restaurant ,that when I received the bill I just looked at the total ,assuming the gratuity was included ,and just split the total between us and the other couple. Once we left ,the waitress chased our friends down and started hassling them about not leaving a tip. My friends were really confused,because they also assumed it was included. They came to look for us to mention it to us and when we turn around to face them ,there was the waitress. I couldn't believe she followed us all the way across the in door plaza. She then stood there with a dirty look at started to almost yell at us in an ugly tone about how we HAD to pay her a tip of $12!! I was really thrown off,but then got upset, . I mean ,last time I checked it was an OPTION to tip someone if you liked the costumer service,and I didn't like their service. If it was mandatory,they should have included it in the bill! I told her she was extremely rude to have done this , and that this had never happen to us before. She just rolled her eyes. At this point,I didn't feel she deserved anything! My boyfriend felt bad and gave her $5 to leave us alone, she then shoved  her hand in front of us to give her more !!! I mean,we had already paid over $80 bucks for shitty service  and food ,we are in a recession!!! Never again will I back here!!! SUper RUDE and CRUDE PEOPLE!!!
author: christy l.

description: Today we had great service.  The dragon role was excellent and I had a very tasty ramen soup, soba and tempura.  They also validated parking. Next time I want to try their curry.
author: M I.

description: Ended up here after trying to get a seat at Suzu noodle house (which is always packed). Started with the Pink Lady roll... was gorgeous - 3 different colored roe. Almost too pretty to eat. But we ate it, and it was delicious. I ordered the Katsu-Don. Some may call me a Donburi snob, but I know what I like. I was unimpressed. I'd come back here for the maki, but will order donburi somewhere else.
author: Nicole Sooah C.

description: friendly prompt service with fresh food they care about. I'm usually seated and fed promptly, and have enjoyed bringing friends here as well.
author: Haoming C.

description: This place is okay. I find it a little pricey, especially during lunch time. Though, my oyakodon was pretty worth it. I forget, but I think it was around $8 or so? I have to admit, it was really good. The chicken was tender and the onions were tasty (i'm usually not fond of onions). My friends ordered some sushi special or something like that, and I found that pricey. One major thing that I must complain is that the sashimi was so not fresh. When my friend picked it up, it started to break and stretch out like an accordion...okay, i'm not really good at describing things, but all i can say is that their raw fish are not fresh. A plus on the other side is that their service is nice. Theres always some one checking up on you constantly. Extra point for that!
author: Vivian C.

description: Our visits to J-town either starts or ends at Kushi Tsuru. Not sure why. Their food is not spectacular, and the venue is not particularly attractive. We've tried the other places in the mall but we always come back to this one. We always either go for the tempura udon on a cold SF day, or the CB special bento (teriyaki chicken with rice, miso soup, salad, and sushi rolls) on a warm day. I guess that's really the reason why. It's comfort food. Plus, it reminds us of those little restaurants we used to squeeze into in Shinjuku. Now if they would only give us those nice little wet naps before each meal, I would give them another star. Itadakimasu.
author: Rey L.

description: Now i love my mom and everything but the thing that drives me crazy is when she says remember "im always rite" and until now i never really was able to disprove that, but when i walked into kushi tsuru i finally got her! she said this place was "great" and that she and her friends used to come her back in the "days". Now seriously that couldve been decades ago! But  to the point kushi tsuru was not great it was alrite, i got the donburi and it was small and very average tasting. Trust me for something like $8.50 take your money to Iroha across the streeet.
author: Brian Y.

description: This one star is for the food. The only thing holding them up from a -8 is the quality of food. The service here was awful. I have never been treated so badly in San Francisco. My friends and I are in high school, and are used to general discrimination. However, tonight was ridiculous. They handed us a stack of menus at the front and they told us to go to the back. Then they took 25 minutes to take our order. The server was very rude to one of my friends because she didn't pronounce what she was ordering correctly. Then we had to actually ASK for tea and water. Then we waited...and waited....and people in the neighboring booth who had come after us (getting much more courteous service) received their food before us. The food was pretty good, I have come here many times before (with a decent level of service) with my family. My friend ordered a $12.50 tonkatsu and tempura combo, and the portion was half of my friends $8.00 donburi. Wtf is with that? And then our tea and water were never refilled. We waited for our check for a long time, after asking the waiter and waitress several times and being brushed off. The host, the one with the glasses, nitpicked with us for 6 cents. SIX FRIGGIN CENTS. *sighs* I dislike this age-profiling shiz. Don't go here if you are younger than 20 or expect any level of service.
author: Shizuka L.

description: another restaurant in the mall that only survives because of its location.  don't believe the white people, this place is for suckers.
author: mark l.

description: I guess I am just a stupid white girl and I don't know anything about Japanese food, so I like this place.  It is a good value and great to grab dinner at before going to Kabuki theater.  I really LOVE the sukiyaki, haven't tried the sushi, but it looks good.  Hey, if this restaurant's  only for tourists, then why do I see Japanese people eating here?
author: jessica d.

description: it's like japanese food. but yknow, the kind they ate there. service is quick, the maguro was fresh, it was yummy.
author: Seiji C.

description: a little lacking in decor.  it's right next to mifune in the mall.  i swear that the food came from the mifune kitchen.  the tori toji tasted sooo similar.  i believe oskaya, mifune, and kushi tsuru all share the same bathroom.  i agree with other reviewers that the staff seems extra nice -- they go out of their way to be cool to you.
author: Tim G.

description: the food isn't the greatest. but its the best place to eat in Japantown and it has incredibly good service. they are very attentative and its relatively cheap and filling. not too mention there is a lot of people eating there.
author: Derek Alistair J.

description: The food is ok - we have had better.  But the service is very good - especially if you have children.  They are patient and bring out child-size utensils.  They don't rush you and they are friendly.  (Can't say that about Maki - please see my review!)  Don't eat the sushi but their grill stuff is pretty good.  Hit and miss with the soybeans.  We go there to get away from the rain (we don't have to go outside from our garage to J-town) and have decent and quick service for the family where we treat them to gelato afterwards.  Highly recommended for families.
author: G. W.

description: food is OK, but service is horrible.  we had to try hard to flag somebody down to order food and some water.  i tried to order sushi because they have different kinds of sushi in the front display, but i was told that they don't do sushi.  they don't validate, they don't say thank you when you are leaving.  i left 10% tip just because, but i know they didn't deserve it.
author: N B.
